title: Alternative investment fund managers: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on Alternative Investment Fund Managers and amending Directives 2004/39/EC and 2009/…/EC
background: Following the 2008 financial crisis and G20 commitments to strengthen financial regulation, the European Commission proposed harmonizing oversight of alternative investment funds in 2009 to address systemic risks and cross-border market integration challenges. The Parliament will discuss establishing EU-wide supervisory frameworks, transparency requirements, and market access rules for alternative investment fund managers.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA completely challenges the proposal's failure to close passive distribution loopholes, enabling unregulated hedge fund products to circulate freely within the EU internal market.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the reliance on national debt limit rules for funds, which contradicts the party's demand for stringent EU-wide crisis-prevention standards and risks regulatory fragmentation.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the inadequate safeguards against private equity asset stripping, overlooking critical protections for workers' rights and small-to-medium enterprises.  
GREEN_EFA conflicts fundamentally with the issue’s omission of binding transparency requirements, leaving corporate exploitation risks unaddressed despite systemic financial stability concerns.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the disproportionate influence of sectoral lobbying on the directive’s weak framework, which undermines parliamentary efforts to enact meaningful financial sector accountability.

ALDE strongly promotes the establishment of clear framework conditions for alternative investment fund managers, particularly the enhanced transparency measures that align with ALDE's commitment to identifying systemic risks and market stability.  
ALDE approves the EU passport system as a critical advancement for the internal market, emphasizing its phased introduction for third-country managers to maintain global market openness.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s elimination of competition distortions in private equity regulation, which effectively safeguards against asset stripping while preserving fair market practices.  
ALDE proposes ensuring robust coordination with ESMA during the transitional period to streamline implementation and minimize operational adjustments for cross-border fund managers.  
ALDE endorses the harmonized supervisory architecture as a strategic step toward a common rulebook, reflecting ALDE's priority of integrating best practices across EU financial markets.

SD strongly accepts the directive’s transparency and investor protection measures, aligning perfectly with their commitment to financial market accountability and safeguarding citizen investments.  
SD applauds the anti-asset stripping provisions as effectively advancing worker protections and sustainable corporate governance, particularly the two-year capital lock-in and mandatory employee consultation.  
SD endorses the expanded ESMA oversight powers, recognizing this as a critical step toward robust EU-level supervision of alternative funds to mitigate systemic risks.  
SD proposes a Commission-led market impact assessment by 2015 to ensure harmonization achieves stability without distortions, enhancing post-implementation review mechanisms.  
SD emphasizes the issue’s alignment with their manifesto through strict leverage limits and deferred bonus structures, curbing short-term risk incentives in fund management.

GUE/NGL fundamentally rejects the diluted regulation of private equity firms, citing the Council’s capitulation to financial lobbyists as enabling speculative risks inconsistent with worker protections.  
GUE/NGL opposes the issue’s passive marketing loophole, which permits unadvertised predatory practices akin to “selling rotten eggs” without transparency safeguards.  
GUE/NGL condemns the erosion of workforce information rights, noting that weakened obligations for owners to inform employees betray commitments to labor justice.  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal’s failure to address systemic dangers, as it neglects bans on hedge funds and derivatives while tolerating tax havens.  
GUE/NGL asserts the text overlooks critical public control mechanisms, contradicting their demand for political oversight of all financial transactions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2009 proposal, urging the Commission to resubmit the matter to Parliament if it substantially amends or replaces the proposal, and directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. The resolution, grounded in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and procedural rules, emphasized adherence to interinstitutional procedures following the Lisbon Treaty’s implementation, while endorsing the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report and the Legal Affairs Committee’s opinion to formalize Parliament’s stance for further legislative deliberation.

title: European Central Bank annual report (2011): REPORT on 2011 Annual Report of the European Central Bank
background: In 2011, the eurozone faced slowing GDP growth (1.5%), rising unemployment (10.7%), and inflation (2.7%), alongside ECB measures including interest rate adjustments, long-term refinancing operations (LTRO), and bond purchases under the Securities Markets Programme. The Parliament will discuss ECB policy effectiveness, financial stability risks, and institutional accountability under EU treaties.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue’s endorsement of ECB liquidity operations, citing their diversion to sovereign debt speculation rather than SME lending as evidence of systemic failure.  
EFD opposes the banking union framework for institutionalizing moral hazard through shared liability schemes that transfer bank insolvency costs to taxpayers.  
EFD condemns the ECB’s political interference in national governance, exemplified by pressure on Italian and Greek governments during debt restructurings.  
EFD absolutely challenges austerity-driven fiscal consolidation, blaming ECB-backed Troika programs for record unemployment and suppressed growth.  
EFD challenges the issue’s transparency rhetoric as inadequate given continued refusal to disclose SMP bond purchase prices and collateral risk exposures.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on enhanced transparency and democratic accountability, which aligns perfectly with their commitment to institutional reform and public oversight of financial governance.  
GREEN_EFA approves the urgency of completing the banking union with a single supervisory mechanism, as this directly addresses systemic risks highlighted in their advocacy for financial stability through structural integration.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening the issue’s focus on private debt reduction alongside public debt consolidation to reflect broader economic vulnerabilities, noting the ECB’s current imbalance in addressing sovereign liabilities alone.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for conditional lending to SMEs and growth-oriented policies, which effectively advances their priority of equitable economic recovery over austerity-driven measures.  
GREEN_EFA urges explicit inclusion of tax justice provisions in future ECB recommendations to combat corporate tax avoidance, framing this as a necessary enhancement to fiscal fairness within monetary policy frameworks.

SD strongly promotes the ECB’s decisive non-conventional measures like LTROs and OMT, which align with S&D’s commitment to combating financial speculation and stabilizing employment across the eurozone.  
SD approves the issue’s emphasis on banking union completion, particularly the single supervisory mechanism, as this directly advances S&D’s institutional reform agenda for democratic economic governance.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of redirecting ECB liquidity to SMEs and youth employment programs, reflecting S&D’s core priority of inclusive growth given SMEs employ 72% of the workforce.  
SD urges enhanced transparency in collateral reporting and gender parity in ECB leadership, proposing concrete amendments to publish bond purchase prices and accelerate gender-balanced appointments.  
SD recommends extending the Troika accountability framework to include systematic parliamentary oversight of debt restructuring terms, ensuring equal treatment for all program countries.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's endorsement of ECB crisis measures that transfer sovereign debt risks to public balance sheets while failing to address austerity's social devastation.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the Troika's anti-democratic operations, demanding full abolition rather than mere "enhanced oversight" of its destructive programs.  
GUE_NGL condemns the ECB's financial coercion tactics exemplified in Cyprus as criminal extortion contradicting basic democratic principles.  
GUE_NGL denounces the SMP's market distortions that prioritize bondholder profits over workers' needs, worsening inequality across crisis states.  
GUE_NGL refuses to legitimize the ECB's unconstitutional mandate expansion through Troika participation without Treaty reform.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the eurozone's economic slowdown, with real GDP growth declining from 1.9% in 2010 to 1.5% in 2011 and unemployment rising to 10.7%, alongside significant youth unemployment. It noted the ECB’s monetary policy actions, including two interest rate hikes (25 basis points each in April and August 2011) followed by two reductions (25 basis points each in November and December 2011), and the launch of three-year Long-Term Refinancing Operations (LTROs) totaling over €1 trillion (€489.2 billion in December 2011 and €529.5 billion in February 2012) to stabilize financial markets. Despite these efforts, credit growth to the private sector slowed sharply (from 1.6% in 2010 to 0.4% in 2011), inflation rose to 2.7% (driven by energy prices), and government debt increased to 88% of GDP. The resolution acknowledged the ECB’s Securities Markets Programme (SMP), which temporarily reduced borrowing costs for struggling states, but criticized structural shortcomings, including risks from transferring sovereign and bank liabilities to the ECB’s balance sheet (now over 30% of eurozone GDP) and excessive reliance on non-marketable collateral (23% of total). It urged greater transparency, including publication of collateral details, voting records, and SMP bond purchase prices, and called for conditional lending to boost SME credit, which employs 72% of the workforce. The Parliament stressed the urgency of a banking union with a single supervisory mechanism (SSM), resolution authority, and deposit guarantees, while safeguarding against conflicts between monetary and supervisory roles. It criticized the ECB’s lack of gender parity in leadership and insufficient accountability of the Troika, demanding enhanced parliamentary oversight. Finally, the resolution emphasized the need for growth-oriented policies, fiscal consolidation, and Treaty revisions to address institutional gaps and reinforce democratic accountability in ECB operations.

title: European Central Bank annual report for 2012: REPORT on the European Central Bank Annual report for 2012
background: In 2012, the eurozone faced economic contraction, rising unemployment, sovereign debt pressures, and banking sector fragility, prompting ECB interventions including long-term refinancing operations and bond purchase programs. The Parliament will discuss ECB monetary policy tools, banking union implementation, financial stability mechanisms, and central bank accountability during the crisis response.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the issue's emphasis on targeted ECB measures for SMEs, advising the inclusion of securitized loan purchases to alleviate credit constraints while maintaining sterilization protocols.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of finalizing the Single Resolution Mechanism to complement the SSM, noting that fragmented issue frameworks risk perpetuating bank-sovereign dependencies.  
EPP advises addressing credit market fragmentation by mandating ECB transparency on national lending disparities, particularly for SMEs facing 8%+ borrowing cost gaps between member states.  
EPP highlights concerns that prolonged near-zero interest rates could replicate Japan’s deflationary stagnation, urging quarterly impact assessments on savings and investment channels.  
EPP stresses monitoring non-eurozone spillover effects, particularly non-performing loans in subsidiaries like Romania’s 80% foreign-owned banks, to prevent cross-border credit retrenchment.

EFD rejects the issue’s endorsement of ECB-led privatization mandates, which undermine national autonomy and mirror past detrimental policies like the "grand sell-off" of Italian assets.  
EFD opposes the creation of a common bank issue fund, arguing it socializes losses from weak banks’ toxic loans while obscuring accountability, contrary to fiscal responsibility principles.  
EFD entirely disputes with the issue’s reliance on ECB liquidity injections, viewing prolonged debt monetization as unsustainable and a systemic collapse risk.  
EFD criticizes the omission of debt forgiveness for governments and banks, a stance aligned with their advocacy for direct relief over austerity-driven reforms.  
EFD dismisses centralized monetary policies as incompatible with addressing regional disparities, advocating instead for nationalist economic sovereignty to protect productive sectors.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's inflation-centric approach as fully rejecting with urgent deflation prevention priorities highlighted in ECB policy debates.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the inadequate measures for real economy credit access, citing the rejected amendments to bind ECB liquidity recipients to increase SME lending as critical oversight.  
GREEN_EFA fully rejects with the issue's tolerance of ECB encroachment into fiscal/social policies, mirroring Lamberts' condemnation of Draghi's labor market flexibilization pressures.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the insufficient democratic accountability framework, noting the issue's failure to address ECB's Troika role normalization demands from Joly's intervention.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the growth strategy's silence on social protections, aligning with critiques that ECB policies accelerate erosion of Europe's welfare models.

ALDE supports with suggestions the emphasis on structural reforms and Banking Union completion, advising stricter safeguards to ensure LTRO liquidity reaches SMEs rather than government debt.  
ALDE advises enhancing the ECB’s medium-term strategy to revive the 2012 comprehensive approach integrating fiscal, banking, and political union goals, as raised in concerns about fragmented progress.  
ALDE cautions against prolonged reliance on unconventional monetary measures without parallel national reforms, aligning with issue warnings about delayed structural adjustments due to low rates.  
ALDE urges revising LTRO terms to prevent crowding-out effects, citing Spain’s 11% credit contraction to firms versus rising bank holdings of sovereign debt as contrary to issue priorities for SME financing.  
ALDE endorses transparency improvements like publishing meeting minutes but proposes accelerating gender balance reforms in ECB leadership beyond current issue language.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the eurozone's economic challenges, including a 0.6% GDP contraction in 2012, projected 0.4% decline in 2013, and unemployment rising to 11.4% in 2012 (12.2% in 2013), with youth unemployment and disparities between member states worsening. It noted the ECB’s monetary measures, such as reducing interest rates to a historic low of 0.5% in 2013, injecting over €1 trillion via long-term refinancing operations (LTROs), and launching Outright Monetary Transactions (OMTs) conditional on ESM programs to stabilize sovereign debt markets. However, it highlighted risks from prolonged low rates, fragmented credit markets (e.g., Spain’s 8% annual credit contraction), and impaired monetary transmission, stressing SMEs’ critical role (98% of firms, 72% of employment) and their higher borrowing costs. The resolution urged targeted ECB support for SMEs, including purchasing securitized loans, while emphasizing sterilization to curb inflation risks. It welcomed the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) to sever bank-sovereign links but called for a Single Resolution Mechanism, improved ECB transparency, and accountability, including publishing meeting minutes and addressing gender imbalance in leadership. Concerns included rising ELA lines (€206 billion in 2012), TARGET II imbalances, and excessive reliance on ECB liquidity, urging a balanced exit from accommodative policies once stability improves. It criticized delayed reforms due to low rates and stressed adherence to EU treaties prohibiting monetary financing of governments, advocating growth-focused policies to restore market confidence and cohesion.

title: European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority
background: Following the 2008 financial crisis and the de Larosière Report (2009), which identified fragmented national oversight in integrated EU financial markets, the European Commission proposed reforms in 2009 to strengthen cross-border supervision under the Treaty of Lisbon. The Parliament will discuss establishing a European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority to enhance EU financial stability.

stances.stance:
EPP completely advocates the issue's framework for establishing cross-border supervisory mechanisms as perfectly aligning with its commitment to EU financial stability.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the emphasis on ECB-led systemic risk management, recognizing the Central Bank's proven crisis leadership capabilities.  
EPP completely advocates direct intervention rights for supervisory authorities, affirming the necessity of supranational oversight for transnational financial institutions.  
EPP perfectly supports the issue's integration of Central/Eastern European representation requirements in risk governance structures.  
EPP completely advocates binding timelines for operationalizing supervisory bodies by January 2011, matching its priority for crisis-prevention urgency.

EFD conditionally supports the issue's supervisory framework but demands amendment of Article 7 to prevent excessive centralization that would reduce national authorities to "agent" roles.  
EFD firmly disapproves the Frankfurt headquarters designation in Recital 22 as geopolitically biased, insisting on relocation criteria prioritizing financial hubs like Milan.  
EFD requests insertion of binding derivatives market controls in Section IV-A to address what the issue "fails to address" as the crisis' primary cause.  
This conflicts with EFD's principle that EU oversight must maintain local monitoring capacities, as explicitly rejected in Paragraph 34's agency empowerment clauses.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as bank transaction taxation mechanisms, inconsistent with Borghezio-Rossi amendments proposed during committee review.

GREEN_EFA absolutely sanctions the issue’s emphasis on harmonized European supervision for cross-border insurance actors, perfectly aligning with their commitment to supranational regulatory coherence under Article 114 TFEU.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the prohibition of toxic financial products, as highlighted in the debate, affirming the issue’s implicit prioritization of consumer protection and systemic stability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for binding EU-level actions to counter national egotism, which advances their vision of a political federation as a safeguard against continental decline.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the urgency of institutional accountability, mirroring the issue’s procedural safeguards to ensure Parliament’s re-engagement on substantive amendments.  
GREEN_EFA champions the debate’s linkage between monetary and economic federation, resonating with the issue’s foundational alignment with Lisbon Treaty integration principles.

GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the fragmented supervisory framework for perpetuating inadequate control over financial markets, inconsistent with their demand for a unified European Financial Supervisory Authority.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s failure to mandate stringent capital rules and uniform regulations across Member States, contradicting their imperative to dismantle predatory financial capitalism.  
GUE_NGL condemns the diluted intervention rights as a capitulation to Council interests, overlooking critical safeguards needed to protect democracy and social stability.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s negligence in addressing systemic crisis risks, opposing its complacency toward brewing economic collapses warned by figures like Alessandro Profumo.  
GUE_NGL disputes the procedural emphasis on legal coherence under TFEU Article 114, arguing it sidelines urgent regulatory action required to avert future social devastation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2009 proposal (COM(2009)0502) to harmonize legislation under Article 95 of the EC Treaty (now Article 114 TFEU), emphasizing alignment with the Treaty of Lisbon’s procedural implications (COM(2009)0665). It adopted its first-reading stance based on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report (A7‑0170/2010) and considered opinions from the Committees on Budgets, Legal Affairs, and Constitutional Affairs. The resolution underscored the need for legal coherence under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 294(3) and 114) and sought to ensure the Commission re-engages Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. It also highlighted the role of the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2010 opinion in shaping the legislative process, while instructing institutional stakeholders to advance the adopted position.

title: European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority and European Securities and Markets Authority: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directives 2003/71/EC and 2009/138/EC in respect of the powers of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority and the European Securities and Markets Authority
background: Following post-2008 financial sector reforms, the European System of Financial Supervision established in 2010 required adjustments to regulatory mandates for insurance and securities oversight. The Parliament will discuss amendments to EU directives concerning supervisory authorities' roles in financial stability and single market integration.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA rejects the amendments to Articles 25a and 256a for enabling reduced capital transparency, which directly undermines systemic stability and consumer safeguards.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the deletion of Article 301(2)-(3), as it weakens oversight of Solvency Capital Requirement models and contradicts principles of rigorous financial accountability.  
This issue conflicts irreconcilably with GREEN_EFA’s mandate to prioritize consumer protection, particularly in permitting lowered capital reserves (€200 billion scale) without compensatory safeguards.  
The amendments to Regulation 1060/2009 Article 2(3) fail to address Greens/EFA demands for stringent credit rating agency supervision, risking repeat crises from biased risk assessments.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s reliance on actuarial manipulations in Articles 114 and 176, which prioritize industry profitability over policyholder security.

ALDE strongly upholds the enhanced transparency measures in Articles 6, 7, 9, and 12, which align perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to market stability and consumer protection through rigorous disclosure of authorization processes and asset quality.  
ALDE approves the refined governance requirements in Articles 149, 155, and 159, effectively advancing their priority of harmonized supervisory reporting and systemic risk mitigation across EU member states.  
ALDE highlights the critical need for delegated acts to codify proportionality principles from the November 13 agreement, ensuring obligations scale precisely with insurers’ size and risk profiles as outlined in amended Regulation 1060/2009.  
ALDE commends the issue’s alignment with long-term economic financing goals, particularly the safeguards against excessive short-term volatility in Solvency Capital Requirement models under Article 176.  
ALDE acknowledges the necessity of future international harmonization efforts, urging the Commission to prioritize global regulatory coherence in line with EIOPA’s expanded mandate under Article 25a.

SD strongly accepts the updated authorization processes and transparency requirements in Article 25a, which align perfectly with their commitment to consumer protection through rigorous supervisory oversight.  
SD applauds the enhanced EIOPA mandates on occupational pensions oversight as effectively advancing worker security, matching their 2023 social protection priorities for robust retirement safeguards.  
SD approves the third-country recognition framework revisions for maintaining global competitiveness while ensuring regulatory equivalence, reflecting their balanced approach to single market integrity.  
SD proposes clarifying "group structure" definitions in Article 256a through delegated acts to prevent regulatory arbitrage without delaying implementation timelines.  
SD endorses the harmonized Solvency II technical standards as critical for systemic stability, directly supporting their post-crisis financial reform agenda.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's capital requirement framework (Articles 6, 7, 9) for permitting excessive risk-taking in pension investments, endangering retirees' financial security.  
GUE_NGL opposes the amendments to Article 256a on group structures, arguing they enable systemic opacity and replicate the "privatized profits, socialized losses" model condemned in banking crises.  
GUE_NGL entirely disputes with the authorization processes under Article 25a, deeming publication requirements inadequate to enforce real-time asset-liability verification for insurers.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to mandate absolute solvency guarantees, leaving pension users exposed to market-driven collapses contrary to social protection principles.  
GUE_NGL criticizes the deletion of Article 301(2-3) as weakening supervisory accountability, risking delayed intervention in insurer insolvencies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised amendments to Directive 2002/92/EC and Regulation (EC) No 1060/2009, focusing on enhancing regulatory frameworks for financial services. Key revisions included updating provisions on authorization processes, regulatory technical standards for own funds eligibility, Solvency Capital Requirement internal models, and qualitative requirements for insurers. Specific changes involved inserting Article 25a to mandate notification and publication of authorizations, withdrawals, and refusals, and Article 256a to regulate group structures. The resolution deleted paragraphs 2 and 3 of Article 301 and amended Article 2(3) of Regulation 1060/2009 to refine credit rating agency oversight. Multiple articles (e.g., Articles 6, 7, 9, 12, 114, 149, 155, 159, 176, 242, 247) were revised to strengthen transparency, align with technical standards, and ensure consistent application of rules across member states, particularly regarding capital requirements, internal governance, and supervisory reporting. The amendments aimed to harmonize EU financial regulations, improve consumer protection, and bolster systemic stability.

title: ECB annual report for 2010: REPORT on the ECB Annual Report for 2010
background: In 2010, the euro area experienced moderate GDP recovery alongside rising sovereign debt levels and sustained low inflation, prompting ECB interventions in bond markets through securities purchase programs amid ongoing financial instability. The Parliament will discuss the European Central Bank’s crisis response measures and eurozone fiscal governance challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the ECB’s crisis response measures, including bond purchases and liquidity provisions, which align with their commitment to safeguarding the euro’s stability amid financial turmoil.  
EPP approves enhanced transparency in ECB collateral valuation and risk management, particularly endorsing public access to Governing Council meeting minutes to bolster institutional credibility.  
EPP advocates for accelerated Treaty revisions to establish a European Monetary Fund and eurobonds, framing this as a necessary evolution of fiscal governance consistent with their integration principles.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of growth-oriented policies and coordinated central bank actions, aligning with their priority to restore market confidence while maintaining price stability.  
EPP proposes exploring mechanisms for the ECB to act as a lender of last resort, viewing this as a strategic enhancement to address asymmetric impacts of monetary policy across Member States.

ALDE strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on ECB independence, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to institutional integrity and Treaty-based monetary governance.  
ALDE applauds the call for unified euro-area representation in international bodies, effectively advancing ALDE’s priority of deepening political and economic integration.  
ALDE proposes enhancing communication discipline within the ECB Governing Council to prevent fragmented public narratives, while fully endorsing the issue’s transparency demands on collateral valuation.  
ALDE strongly approves the creation of a European Finance Minister and Treasury, recognizing this as critical to resolving asymmetric impacts of monetary policy across member states.  
ALDE approves the swift implementation of the European Stability Mechanism, urging treaty-based institutionalization to strengthen crisis-response frameworks.

ECR rejects the issue's push for a European credit rating foundation, viewing it as redundant centralization that conflicts with their principle of market-led financial accountability.  
ECR opposes the creation of a European Monetary Fund, arguing it institutionalizes bailout dependency instead of enforcing national fiscal discipline as advocated in their debate interventions.  
ECR fully disputes with the proposal for a single European Finance Minister, deeming it a direct erosion of subsidiarity and member state sovereignty over economic governance.  
The issue’s emphasis on ECB liquidity operations overlooks critical risks of politicizing monetary policy, contradicting ECR’s insistence on absolute central bank independence.  
ECR criticizes the European Stability Mechanism’s treaty-external framework as inconsistent with their demand for transparent, treaty-anchored EU fiscal safeguards.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s endorsement of ECB policies that prioritize austerity and financial sector interests over democratic accountability and social welfare.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the portrayal of ECB independence, which masks its role in enforcing undemocratic austerity regimes and replacing elected governments with technocratic rule.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects such as the ECB’s complicity in widening economic disparities through interest rate hikes and bond market speculation, directly contradicting GUE_NGL’s anti-austerity principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to address the ECB’s coercive tactics, exemplified by its threat to withhold bond purchases unless Italy imposed brutal cuts to public services and workers’ rights.  
This fundamentally condemns with GUE_NGL’s demand to abolish ECB policies that institutionalize corporate power and deepen the crisis of legitimacy in EU economic governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined key economic and monetary policy issues, noting the euro area’s 2010 GDP growth of 1.7% and projected 1.6% growth in 2011, alongside rising public deficits (6.0% of GDP) and debt (85.1% of GDP) compared to pre-crisis levels. It highlighted the ECB’s role in maintaining price stability, with 2010 inflation at 1.6%, and acknowledged the ECB’s non-standard measures, including the Securities Markets Programme (EUR 129 billion in bond purchases by September 2011) and covered bond purchases (EUR 60 billion). The resolution expressed alarm over persistent financial turmoil, sovereign debt strains, and asymmetric impacts of ECB interest rate hikes (from 1% in 2010 to 1.5% by July 2011) on weaker economies. It criticized unsustainable pre-crisis private and public debt levels, urging stronger fiscal governance, a European credit rating foundation, and a European Monetary Fund to reduce reliance on external institutions. The Parliament called for transparency in ECB collateral valuation and risk management, particularly regarding asset-backed securities (EUR 480 billion held in 2010) and liquidity operations. It emphasized the need for a single European Finance Minister and Treasury, enhanced economic governance, and swift implementation of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), while criticizing its establishment outside EU treaties. The resolution also stressed macroprudential supervision, balanced application of fiscal rules, and ECB accountability, welcoming Estonia’s euro adoption and advocating for a unified euro-area representation in international bodies like the IMF.

title: European social entrepreneurship funds: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European Social Entrepreneurship Funds
background: The European Commission's 2011 proposal under Article 114 TFEU sought to address fragmented funding access for social enterprises, which represent 10% of EU businesses and rely heavily on declining public grants. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures to establish a European framework for social entrepreneurship funds, aiming to improve capital access and market integration.

stances.stance:
EFD slightly endorses the social objectives but demands explicit fraud prevention mechanisms in Article 6, referencing Italy's ESF misuse cases  
EFD requests revisions to establish third-party monitoring requirements for all fund allocations under Chapter III  
The proposal completely conflicts with EFD's principle of fiscal accountability by lacking concrete penalties for speculative fund diversion  
EFD warns the current criteria framework risks replicating disability sector vulnerabilities through inadequate beneficiary verification protocols  
This overlooks critical aspects of local implementation controls, inconsistent with EFD's demands for decentralized audit authority

ALDE strongly accepts the harmonized European passport system for social entrepreneurship funds, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to single market integration and SME financing accessibility.  
ALDE applauds the elimination of redundant depositary requirements, effectively advancing their priority of streamlining cross-border investment processes while maintaining investor protections.  
ALDE approves the issue’s emphasis on venture capital diversification as critical to fostering innovation-driven growth, consistent with their economic modernization agenda.  
ALDE proposes enhancing collaboration mechanisms to address tax haven exploitation risks, framing this as a necessary complement to the framework’s market integration goals.  
ALDE endorses the crisis-responsive focus on social entrepreneurship development, recognizing its alignment with their strategies for sustainable economic recovery and job creation.

SD fully sanctions the harmonization of European social entrepreneurship funds, perfectly aligning with their commitment to economic growth and social innovation through standardized investor frameworks.  
SD perfectly aligns with the establishment of a passport system for social investment funds, emphasizing enhanced investor confidence and mobilization of savings into the real economy as critical to crisis recovery.  
SD urges the Council to promptly finalize the agreed framework, highlighting the critical need for unified action amidst ongoing economic challenges to prevent procedural delays undermining social entrepreneurship.  
SD proposes strengthening measures against tax havens and systemic tax fraud, ensuring the issue’s integrity matches its ambitious social goals by closing regulatory loopholes.  
SD commends the balanced investor protections and growth-oriented provisions as a model for future EU-wide social economy initiatives, reflecting SD’s manifesto priorities for equitable investment.

GUE_NGL totally againsts with the issue's restrictive definition of social enterprises, which reduces their scope to addressing vulnerability rather than recognizing their broader role in sustainable development and participatory governance.  
GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to legally distinguish social economy enterprises from capital-driven models, contradicting their advocacy for cooperative ownership and profit-reinvestment principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the legislative sequencing that prioritizes financial frameworks over holistic recognition of social economies, as critiqued by Vergiat’s emphasis on status differentiation.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s inadequacy in preventing social ‘washing’ by omitting stringent criteria for enterprise governance and community benefit mandates.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0862, C7‑0489/2011) to harmonize legislation under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing the need for legal alignment across member states. It endorsed the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report (A7-0194/2012), incorporating opinions from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Legal Affairs, while considering input from the European Economic and Social Committee (2012) and the European Central Bank. The resolution called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements were planned and instructed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity in the legislative process.

title: European venture capital funds: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European Venture Capital Funds
background: Fragmented EU venture capital markets and limited SME access to finance post-2008 crisis prompted the European Commission’s 2011 proposal for a standardized regulatory framework to establish a "European Venture Capital Fund" label, aiming to facilitate cross-border fundraising. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing rules to expand investment channels for SMEs and social enterprises.

stances.stance:
EPP completely accepts the EU-wide venture capital passport framework, perfectly aligning with their strategic priority to stimulate SME growth through innovative financing instruments.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's harmonization objectives, recognizing their critical role in overcoming market fragmentation and enabling cross-border venture capital deployment.  
EPP strongly accepts the inclusion of social entrepreneurship provisions, advocating their potential to legitimize impact-focused business models while emphasizing rigorous anti-abuse mechanisms as inherent strengths of the proposal.  
EPP endorses the accelerated implementation timeline, highlighting its consistency with their manifesto commitment to job creation via knowledge-intensive enterprise development.  
EPP applauds the issue’s alignment with private capital mobilization strategies, particularly its integration of sector-specific expertise sharing to maximize startup scalability.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on proving genuine social benefit for companies receiving investments, aligning perfectly with GREEN_EFA’s commitment to preventing superficial labeling and ensuring substantive social impact.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the inclusion of support for social housing and developing-country institutions, effectively advancing the party’s priority of global equity and addressing systemic poverty through EU financial instruments.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening Article 4 by explicitly excluding investments in tax havens, urging the Council to adopt a binding European definition to prevent misuse of social economy funds.  
GREEN_EFA approves the streamlined bureaucratic framework for venture capital funds, recognizing its potential to accelerate green innovation and social entrepreneurship across member states.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s coherence with broader EU social economy initiatives as critical for building sustainable financial ecosystems, while advocating for stricter due diligence clauses in future amendments.

SD entirely endorses the venture capital passport framework, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to mobilizing EU savings for innovation-driven economic growth.  
SD applauds the issue’s investor protection mechanisms as a critical advancement in building confidence for social economy investments, reflecting SD’s manifesto priorities.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of Council action to finalize the negotiated agreement, proposing strengthened procedural efficiency to prevent delays in crisis-responsive legislation.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with combating tax evasion, urging future initiatives to close loopholes in tax haven definitions as a natural extension of this framework.  
SD perfectly supports the issue’s harmonization of venture capital markets, recognizing its role in advancing SD’s vision for a socially equitable single market.

GUE/NGL rejects the proposal’s restrictive definition of social enterprises as totally disputeing with their commitment to recognizing partnership-based social economy models distinct from capital-driven entities.  
GUE/NGL opposes the issue’s narrow framing of social enterprises around vulnerability, which overlooks their broader role in sustainable development and inclusive economic systems.  
GUE/NGL condemns the failure to address social “washing” risks, arguing the proposal lacks safeguards to ensure genuine social impact over profit maximization.  
GUE/NGL demands amendments to explicitly prioritize tax frameworks supporting social enterprise funds, absent in the current text despite being critical to their manifesto goals.  
 While acknowledging social enterprises’ potential, GUE/NGL deems the proposal structurally incompatible with anti-capitalist principles governing equitable resource distribution.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0860) concerning harmonization under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance based on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report and the Legal Affairs Committee’s opinion (A7-0193/2012). It emphasized the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending substantial amendments, ensuring legislative coherence under the ordinary legislative procedure. The resolution underscored adherence to Treaty provisions, particularly Article 294, and directed the Parliament’s President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and inter-institutional accountability.

title: Financial assistance for Member States whose currency is not the euro: INTERIM REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation establishing a facility for providing financial assistance for Member States whose currency is not the Euro
background: The global financial crisis strained EU economies, prompting expanded financial assistance mechanisms. Non-euro area states accessed a Balance of Payments (BoP) facility, increased from €12 billion to €50 billion (2008-2009), while eurozone states utilized the European Stability Mechanism (€500 billion). The Parliament will discuss aligning financial assistance frameworks for non-euro and eurozone members.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the BoP facility expansion to €50 billion as a critical step toward financial parity between euro and non-euro states, aligning perfectly with their commitment to cohesive EU economic governance.  
EPP applauds the integration of conditionality requirements mirroring eurozone stability mechanisms, effectively advancing their priority of ensuring sound fiscal policies across all Member States.  
EPP proposes clarifying Article 6 provisions on bank recapitalization access to ensure non-euro states' eligibility under Single Supervisory Mechanism oversight frameworks while maintaining national parliamentary prerogatives.  
EPP endorses leveraging the BoP mechanism to enhance administrative capacities for EU fund absorption, directly advancing cohesion policy objectives through improved structural fund utilization.  
EPP emphasizes the need for explicit subsidiarity safeguards in final regulation text while maintaining full support for streamlined BoP activation procedures under Article 352 TFEU.

EFD rejects the proposal's reliance on new financial instruments that institutionalize divisions between euro and non-euro states, contrary to the issue's parity objectives.  
EFD opposes fundamentally the creation of separate loan mechanisms, which they argue would permanently fragment EU banking systems rather than unify them.  
This conflicts with EFD's insistence on Treaty-based solutions through ESM reform instead of ad hoc tools requiring disproportionate EU oversight.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of legal coherence by bypassing established eurozone stabilization frameworks in favor of untested structures.  
EFD deems the issue inconsistent with subsidiarity principles by expanding centralized financial assistance without explicit national parliamentary ratification mechanisms.

SD fundamentally supports the expansion of the Balance of Payments facility to €50 billion as a critical step toward parity between euro and non-euro states, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to equitable EU solidarity mechanisms.  
SD applauds the issue's emphasis on creating a dedicated bank recapitalization instrument for non-euro states, which directly addresses SD's priority to prevent market fragmentation and ensure equal depositor protection across all Member States.  
SD emphasizes that the proposed alignment of BoP activation procedures with eurozone mechanisms under Regulation (EC) No 332/2002 effectively advances SD's vision of institutional fairness in crisis response frameworks.  
SD strongly accepts the mandatory integration of Article 352 TFEU as the legal basis for future assistance, recognizing its alignment with SD's longstanding advocacy for treaty-compliant financial safeguards.  
SD highlights the issue's call for explicit subsidiarity checks under Article 5 of Protocol No 2 as a necessary enhancement to uphold national parliamentary sovereignty, consistent with SD's democratic accountability principles.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal as it fundamentally againsts with their opposition to austerity policies imposed through undemocratic EU mechanisms.  
GUE_NGL opposes the parity argument, asserting it masks the exportation of neoliberal austerity to non-euro states akin to Troika programs in Greece and Portugal.  
GUE_NGL highlights the democratic deficit in the process, condemning the symbolic parliamentary role that legitimizes austerity without substantive amendments.  
GUE_NGL condemns the alignment with European Stability Mechanism logic, which prioritizes fiscal discipline over social welfare and public sector integrity.  
GUE_NGL warns that the BoP facility perpetuates systemic inequality by enforcing wage cuts and pension reforms under the guise of "financial assistance."

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding the Balance of Payments (BoP) facility, emphasizing its role in addressing financial instability in non-euro area Member States. It noted the facility’s increased capacity from €12 billion to €50 billion, with €13.4 billion disbursed to Romania, Latvia, and Hungary, and a €1.4 billion precautionary reserve for Romania. The resolution welcomed the BoP proposal as a step toward parity between euro and non-euro states, acknowledging challenges due to existing euro-area mechanisms like the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), which has a €500 billion lending capacity and potential direct bank recapitalization. It stressed the need for democratic accountability and alignment with national parliamentary functions, while advocating for updated Regulation (EC) No 332/2002 to streamline BoP activation. The Parliament endorsed Article 352 TFEU as the legal basis for new financial assistance frameworks beyond Article 143 TFEU but criticized the omission of subsidiarity and proportionality principles under Article 5 of Protocol No 2, urging the Commission and Council to explicitly address these before finalizing the regulation. Additionally, it highlighted the BoP’s potential to enhance administrative capacity for absorbing EU funds and called for equitable treatment of all Member States in financial support mechanisms.

title: Access to basic banking services: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on Access to Basic Banking Services
background: Approximately 30 million EU adults lacked access to basic banking services, hindering economic participation and social inclusion. Disparities in Member States' implementation of prior Commission recommendations and existing payment service frameworks contributed to financial exclusion. The Parliament will discuss measures to ensure universal access to essential banking services across the EU.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the mandate for universal access to basic payment accounts, aligning with their commitment to social inclusion and addressing financial exclusion highlighted in Ireland and Romania.  
EPP approves the prohibition of denial based on income or credit history, ensuring protection for vulnerable consumers as emphasized by members citing barriers to social welfare access.  
EPP endorses harmonized anti-money laundering standards but proposes enhancing due diligence with human-centric assessment methods, reflecting calls to evaluate character and track record alongside automated checks.  
EPP advocates strict enforcement of transparent fee structures to eliminate cross-border disparities, aligning with concerns about abusive charges in Member States like Romania.  
EPP emphasizes integrating financial education campaigns and prepaid solutions, supporting recommendations to inform the public and leverage innovative banking tools.

GREEN_EFA entirely approves the issue’s mandate for universal access to basic payment accounts as a non-negotiable right, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle that financial inclusion is inseparable from social equity and dignity.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the prohibition of account denials based on income or credit history, recognizing this as a critical safeguard against systemic discrimination faced by marginalized groups such as migrants and low-income households.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of harmonized anti-money laundering standards to eliminate regulatory disparities, citing Finland and Denmark’s near-universal coverage as proof that proactive legislation—not market forces—drives inclusion.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of prepaid and mobile banking solutions, which directly advances their 2012 agenda to democratize digital financial tools and bridge urban-rural service gaps.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the imperative for binding EU-wide enforcement mechanisms, stressing that voluntary bank initiatives have demonstrably failed 6.4 million discouraged adults, necessitating strict compliance monitoring as outlined in Article 4.

ALDE firmly accepts the issue’s mandate for universal access to basic payment accounts, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eradicating financial exclusion as a barrier to EU citizenship and mobility.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with prohibiting account denials based on income or credit history, reflecting Philippe De Backer’s emphasis on non-discriminatory access for marginalized groups and cross-border workers.  
ALDE fully supports cross-border account portability and financial education provisions, echoing the debate’s focus on Erasmus students and mobile citizens needing seamless payment services.  
ALDE unequivocally backs binding legislation by January 2013 if Member States fail to act, mirroring Olle Schmidt’s insistence on elevating basic banking access to a fundamental right requiring EU-level enforcement.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s alignment with successful Nordic models, reinforcing their advocacy for harmonized regulatory standards to eliminate disparities rooted in administrative barriers rather than economic factors.

ECR rejects the issue's premise that access to basic payment accounts constitutes a universal entitlement, entirely rejecting with ECR's principle opposing state-mandated financial service obligations on private institutions.  
ECR opposes the directive's blanket application to all legal residents, citing unresolved contradictions in fee structures and eligibility criteria that overlook critical aspects of Member State economic diversity.  
ECR disputes the harmonized account mandate as incompatible with local solutions like Welsh credit unions, which the issue jeopardizes by overriding community-based financial support systems.  
ECR challenges the anti-discrimination clauses prohibiting refusal based on income or credit history, arguing this undermines banks' risk-assessment autonomy and contradicts responsible lending practices.  
ECR condemns the cross-border portability requirement as inconsistent with subsidiarity, failing to address disproportionate administrative burdens on smaller financial providers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over financial exclusion affecting 30 million EU adults, including 6.4 million discouraged from seeking accounts, with disparities among Member States such as Romania and Bulgaria where only 50% of adults have accounts. It emphasized that access to affordable basic payment services—essential for social inclusion, mobility, and participation in the internal market—is hindered by restrictive practices, residency requirements, and disproportionate anti-money laundering measures. The resolution called for a directive mandating universal access to basic payment accounts for all legal residents, prohibiting denial based on income, credit history, or refusal to purchase additional services, and ensuring transparent, low-cost services (free or capped fees). It urged the Commission to propose legislation by January 2013 if a 2012 assessment confirmed inadequate progress, stressing harmonized standards, simplified customer due diligence, and safeguards against over-indebtedness. The directive should require Member States to enforce provider compliance, monitor refusals, and establish dispute mechanisms, while promoting financial education and cross-border account portability. It highlighted successful legislative models in Finland and Denmark, where near-universal coverage was achieved, and noted that 67% of account penetration disparities stem from regulatory, not economic, factors. The resolution also emphasized integrating prepaid and mobile banking solutions and ensuring non-discriminatory access to payment channels.

title: Access to the activity of credit institutions and the prudential supervision of credit institutions and investment firms: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the access to the activity of credit institutions and the prudential supervision of credit institutions and investment firms and amending Directive 2002/87/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on the supplementary supervision of credit institutions, insurance undertakings and investment firms in a financial conglomerate
background: The 2008 global financial crisis exposed systemic risks in banking sectors, prompting international reforms like Basel III. The EU sought to strengthen financial stability through harmonized banking regulations, addressing capital adequacy and supervision gaps. The Parliament will discuss legislative measures to implement Basel III standards for credit institutions and investment firms.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly approves the issue's capital buffer requirements as perfectly aligning with their commitment to shield taxpayers from future bank bailouts, particularly through systemic risk buffers for critical financial institutions.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the SME supporting factor reduction to 50% risk weight, effectively advancing their priority to channel credit toward Europe's real economy and job-creating enterprises.  
EPP firmly approves the binding bonus caps as critical to eliminating short-term risk incentives, mirroring their manifesto pledge to align financial sector practices with long-term economic stability.  
EPP fully supports the harmonized Basel III implementation across all EU banks, demonstrating leadership in global prudential standards while preserving flexibility for cooperative banking models.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the urgency to finalize the banking union's issue framework, urging accelerated adoption of deposit guarantee schemes to complete the regulatory architecture.

GREEN_EFA completely advocates the issue's systemic risk provisions, perfectly aligning with their mandate to eliminate "too big to fail" institutions through differentiated capital requirements and liquidity rules.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the binding remuneration ratios as a landmark victory against speculative banking cultures, directly advancing their decade-long campaign to sever excessive risk-taking from compensation structures.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the revolutionary country-by-country reporting mandates, recognizing this transparency mechanism as essential for combating tax evasion and aligning financial flows with climate justice imperatives.  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening future iterations by introducing binding leverage ratio requirements to complement risk-weighted asset calculations, ensuring capital buffers reflect true economic exposures.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the cross-institutional collaboration that secured public interest primacy over banking lobby influence, particularly praising parliamentary resolve against member state attempts to dilute systemic reforms.

SD completely accepts the issue’s stringent bonus cap provisions, which align perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to dismantling short-termist banking cultures and ensuring equitable remuneration frameworks that deter excessive risk-taking.  

SD perfectly aligns with the differentiated capital requirements for systemic banks, recognizing this as a critical advancement in prudential supervision to shield taxpayers from future bailouts while safeguarding SME lending and real-economy financing.  

SD unequivocally supports the cross-border harmonization of Basel III rules, emphasizing how the issue effectively advances SD’s priority of systemic financial stability through enforceable EU-wide capital buffers and liquidity standards.  

SD applauds the mandatory country-by-country profit and tax transparency measures, which mirror SD’s 2023 manifesto pledge to combat fiscal evasion and ensure corporate accountability in alignment with public interest.  

SD celebrates the issue’s reinforcement of parliamentary co-legislative authority, viewing it as a decisive step toward curbing regulatory capture and upholding democratic oversight in financial sector governance.

ECR firmly challenges the proposal's failure to implement Basel III standards, creating an unlevel global playing field for EU banks.  
ECR rejects the removal of bail-in provisions prioritizing subordinated debt over taxpayer-funded bailouts, contradicting fiscal responsibility principles.  
ECR opposes the excessive regulatory constraints on national supervisory powers, particularly threatening member states' ability to maintain higher safeguards like the UK ring-fence.  
ECR condemns the proposal's inadequate systemic risk mitigation for financial conglomerates under CRD IV and Solvency II, perpetuating too-big-to-fail vulnerabilities.  
ECR rejects the unresolved accounting standard reforms and lack of director liability measures, failing to prevent future taxpayer exposure to bank failures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s 2011 legislative proposal (COM(2011)0453) on harmonizing professional qualifications, emphasizing compliance with Treaty provisions (Article 53(1) TFEU) and procedural adherence under Article 294 TFEU. It noted the Swedish Parliament’s subsidiarity objection, asserting the proposal overstepped EU competence. The resolution adopted the Parliament’s first-reading position, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. It mandated forwarding the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, and outlined procedural timelines, including a 12-month deadline for final decisions on qualification applications. Key articles (9-21) addressed operational rules for recognition, though specifics were not detailed in the resolution text. The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report (A7-0170/2012) informed the position, prioritizing cross-border workforce mobility while balancing member state autonomy under subsidiarity principles.

title: Action programme for taxation: REPORT on the amended proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing an action programme for taxation in the European Union for the period 2014-2020 (Fiscalis 2020) and repealing Decision No°1482/2007/EC
background: The European Union's existing Fiscalis programme supported tax cooperation and IT systems for cross-border administrative efficiency, amid rising concerns over tax fraud, evasion, and aggressive tax planning affecting single market integrity. The Parliament will discuss establishing a renewed framework to strengthen tax authorities' collaboration and combat fiscal irregularities within the EU.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the Fiscalis 2020 programme's focus on combating tax evasion and money laundering, aligning perfectly with its commitment to fair competition and a business-friendly environment through harmonized tax enforcement.  
EPP approves the cross-border information exchange mechanisms as critical for eliminating unfair advantages and enabling investment-driven job creation, directly advancing its economic growth priorities.  
EPP proposes enhancing provisions for cross-border worker tax coordination to address double payment burdens, ensuring the programme's benefits extend to labor mobility without opposing its core structure.  
EPP endorses the programme's emphasis on joint training and best-practice sharing among tax authorities, recognizing this as essential for combating recurring fraud patterns across Member States.  
EPP emphasizes the need to maintain national tax sovereignty within the programme's framework, particularly regarding corporate tax rates, while fully backing EU-level cooperation against avoidance.

EFD firmly rejects the issue's financial framework as institutionalizing EU tax hypocrisy where bureaucrats avoid contributions while demanding increased national payments.  
EFD rejects the MFF resource increase, arguing it enables continued wasteful spending by unelected EU bodies rather than addressing core taxpayer concerns.  
EFD highlights the issue's failure to mandate uniform corporate taxation, which Mara Bizzotto identifies as perpetuating evasion through regulatory arbitrage.  
EFD condemns the proposal's silence on EU institutions' own tax avoidance schemes, aligning with Godfrey Bloom's critique of systemic bureaucratic hypocrisy.  
 Jaroslav Paška's technical support for anti-fraud cooperation contradicts EFD's overall rejection but insists on strict limits to third-country involvement.

ALDE strongly endorses the Fiscalis 2020 programme as a vital instrument to combat tax fraud and uphold fiscal justice, aligning perfectly with their commitment to EU values and a fair internal market.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s flexible budget allocation framework, which prioritizes efficiency and cross-border cooperation while integrating third countries like Ukraine, advancing EU enlargement goals.  
ALDE proposes amending the evaluation mechanism to require annual progress reports instead of mid-term assessments, ensuring real-time adaptability and transparency in achieving tax governance targets.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need for robust funding, fully endorsing Parliament’s demand for increased MFF resources to address tax evasion’s €100 billion annual cost and strengthen member states’ fiscal capacities.  
ALDE welcomes the focus on IT interoperability and best-practice sharing among tax authorities, which directly advances their manifesto priorities for a digitized, fraud-resistant single market.

GUE_NGL absolutely challenges the issue's failure to address systemic tax evasion through multinational profit shifting and offshore tax havens, contradicting their demand for economic justice.  
GUE_NGL rejects the narrow focus on wage earners and pensioners while exempting corporate tax avoidance mechanisms central to their redistributive agenda.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposal's lack of binding measures against intra-group transactions and tax paradise exploitation, core issues in their anti-austerity platform.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's structural omission of wealth taxation frameworks, directly conflicting with their manifesto commitment to combat fiscal inequality.  
GUE_NGL asserts that maintaining loopholes for multinationals while imposing austerity-era tax audits on workers violates their principle of progressive fiscal solidarity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the financial envelope in the Commission’s proposal, emphasizing that it remains indicative pending agreement on the multiannual financial framework (MFF) for 2014-2020. It reiterated its position that the next MFF requires a minimum 5% increase in resources compared to 2013 levels to address existing priorities, Treaty of Lisbon obligations, and unforeseen challenges, while warning that even this increase would only partially meet EU objectives and solidarity commitments. The resolution urged the Council to clarify which political priorities or projects it would abandon if opposing this resource boost, despite their demonstrated European added value. Parliament adopted its first-reading position, demanded that the Commission re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments, and instructed its President to communicate the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments.

title: Administrative cooperation in the field of taxation: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation
background: Persistent cross-border tax fraud challenges, exacerbated by the 2008 financial crisis and estimated annual EU revenue losses exceeding EUR 200 billion, prompted the European Commission’s 2009 proposal to strengthen administrative cooperation. Existing mechanisms faced operational limitations amid evolving OECD/G20 tax transparency initiatives. The Parliament will discuss enhancing EU member state collaboration in tax enforcement and fraud prevention.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the proposal for tax harmonization as it entirely conflicts with their principle of national sovereignty, viewing it as a centralized imposition akin to a "thieves’ cartel."  
EFD opposes the issue’s underlying premise that administrative cooperation benefits taxpayers, arguing it entrenches bureaucratic power without mandating equal fiscal burdens for EU officials.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as requiring Commission members to pay identical tax rates as citizens, which EFD deems essential to prevent elite privilege.  
EFD fundamentally disputes the environmental taxation rationale, comparing its fear-based justification to medieval religious coercion inconsistent with transparent governance.  
This issue fails to address EFD’s core objection that harmonization enables unchecked extraction of wealth from citizens rather than protecting economic autonomy.

GREEN_EFA fully agrees the issue's mandate for automatic tax information exchange as essential to combating the €200-250 billion annual tax fraud crisis.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for a consolidated corporate tax base to eliminate fiscal dumping that disadvantages SMEs and public revenues.  
GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions sanction mechanisms against tax havens, aligning with their 2023 agenda for global financial justice and developing nations' resource sovereignty.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on country-by-country corporate reporting as critical to verifying legitimate tax payments across jurisdictions.  
GREEN_EFA fully agrees minimum corporate tax thresholds as foundational to harmonization efforts that prevent destructive inter-state competition.

SD absolutely approves the issue's mandate for absolute transparency between Member States, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to combating tax evasion and securing public funds for crisis recovery.  
SD perfectly supports the reverse charge mechanism extension as critical to preventing VAT fraud in emissions trading, advancing SD's climate policy integration with fiscal integrity.  
SD absolutely approves automatic tax information exchange frameworks, recognizing their necessity to dismantle tax havens and uphold global social responsibility per SD's anti-inequality agenda.  
SD perfectly aligns with leveraging administrative cooperation to recover €200 billion annually in lost revenue, ensuring fair contributions to public services and economic stability.  
SD absolutely approves cross-border debt recovery tools as essential to replicating Greece’s reform urgency EU-wide, reflecting SD’s prioritization of robust fiscal governance.

ECR totally doubts the mandatory information-sharing provisions, arguing they conflict with national sovereignty in taxation and jeopardize third-country security cooperation agreements.  
ECR rejects the issue's approach to tax evasion, asserting it overlooks critical drivers like high tax rates and complex systems that incentivize non-compliance.  
ECR opposes the implicit harmonization agenda through mechanisms like the common consolidated corporate tax base, which undermines legitimate tax competition between states.  
ECR rejects automatic exchange of all tax data as excessive state overreach, advocating instead for targeted information-sharing protocols respecting subsidiarity.  
ECR opposes breaching banking secrecy protections, deeming this a disproportionate intrusion into financial privacy rights without proven anti-evasion benefits.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal concerning taxation measures under Articles 113 and 115 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, approving the proposal as amended and urging the Commission to revise its text accordingly under Article 293(2) of the same Treaty. It emphasized the need for the Council to notify Parliament of any deviations from the approved text and to reconsult Parliament if intending to substantially amend the proposal. The resolution underscored procedural adherence post-Lisbon Treaty, referencing the Commission’s communication (COM(2009)0665) on transitional decision-making, and instructed its President to transmit Parliament’s stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with legislative protocols and interinstitutional accountability.

title: Adoption by Estonia of the euro on 1 January 2011: REPORT on the proposal for a Council decision on the adoption by Estonia of the euro on 1 January 2011
background: Estonia, an EU member since 2004, pursued euro adoption by meeting Maastricht criteria, evidenced in 2010 Commission and ECB convergence reports assessing economic stability. The Parliament will discuss procedural compliance with EU economic criteria for eurozone accession.

stances.stance:
EPP totally sanctions Estonia’s exemplary fiscal discipline and adherence to the Maastricht criteria, perfectly aligning with its unwavering commitment to eurozone stability and economic governance.  
EPP applauds Estonia’s leadership as a beacon of confidence in the euro project, reinforcing the PPE Group’s priority of expanding the currency union through rigorous reform compliance.  
EPP emphasizes the issue’s call for vigilance against asset inflation risks, echoing its longstanding advocacy for ECB and Commission action to safeguard macroeconomic balance.  
EPP celebrates Estonia’s accession as a strategic signal of eurozone resilience and eastward integration, advancing the PPE’s vision of a united and disciplined European economic area.  
EPP underscores the issue’s systemic focus on budgetary accountability, mirroring its manifesto principles of rewarding fiscal prudence amid global financial challenges.

ALDE fundamentally agrees Estonia’s exemplary adherence to the Maastricht criteria, perfectly aligning with ALDE’s commitment to stability-oriented economic governance and rigorous fiscal discipline.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on evaluating budgetary impacts of eurozone mechanisms, reinforcing ALDE’s priority of transparent financial accountability in crisis management.  
ALDE fully supports the call for proactive ECB measures to mitigate asset inflation risks, advancing ALDE’s longstanding advocacy for prudent monetary policy coordination.  
ALDE endorses the issue’s focus on systemic economic governance reforms, reflecting ALDE’s vision of a resilient euro area anchored in rule-based convergence.  
ALDE applauds Estonia’s accession as a model of Treaty compliance, exemplifying ALDE’s belief in the euro’s role as a cornerstone of European integration.

SD firmly accepts Estonia’s strict adherence to Maastricht criteria, highlighting its transparent fiscal policy and credible statistics as exemplary for euro area integration.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s focus on mitigating inflation risks, commending Estonia’s balanced approach to interest rates and price stability post-adoption.  
SD applauds Estonia’s role in strengthening economic governance within the euro area, recognizing its low public debt ratio as a model for prudent fiscal management.  
SD emphasizes the symbolic significance of Estonia’s euro adoption, viewing it as reinforcing confidence in monetary union during Europe’s economic challenges.  
SD supports the evaluation of budgetary impacts through EU stability mechanisms, acknowledging Estonia’s preparedness to contribute responsibly post-accession.

ECR slightly accepts Estonia's euro adoption but requests explicit safeguards against automatic participation in eurozone financial stability mechanisms.  
ECR highlights that the issue's emphasis on shared budgetary impacts firmly opposes with their principle rejecting mutualized debt obligations across member states.  
ECR urges amendments to Article 4 provisions on inflation controls, advocating market-led adjustments over ECB interventionist measures.  
ECR stresses the need to revise governance coordination clauses to prevent erosion of national fiscal sovereignty, consistent with their subsidiarity doctrine.  
ECR acknowledges Estonia’s compliance but warns that systemic reforms proposed in the issue risk incentivizing fiscal laxity in other euro-area states.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding Estonia’s adoption of the euro, emphasizing the need for strict adherence to the Maastricht criteria, particularly the importance of reliable, high-quality data for assessing compliance. It called on the Commission to evaluate the potential budgetary impact on Estonia from participating in the euro area’s financial stability mechanisms, including the eurozone rescue package, once it joins the currency union. Additionally, Parliament urged the Commission and the European Central Bank (ECB) to address risks of asset inflation stemming from low interest rates and to report on measures to mitigate such effects. The resolution also highlighted broader systemic challenges, including the need for enhanced economic governance and coordination within the euro area, while stressing the importance of maintaining fiscal discipline and stability-oriented policies.

title: Economic and budgetary surveillance of Member States with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability in the euro area: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the strengthening of economic and budgetary surveillance of Member States experiencing or threatened with serious difficulties with respect to their financial stability in the euro area
background: The euro area faced financial instability due to sovereign debt crises, prompting EU adoption of the 2011 "six-pack" economic governance reforms. Persistent vulnerabilities and risks of cross-border economic spillovers necessitated further regulatory measures. The Parliament will discuss a legislative proposal to enhance economic and budgetary surveillance mechanisms for eurozone states experiencing financial difficulties.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the integration of binding fiscal rules and automatic correction mechanisms into EU legislation, ensuring strict adherence to Stability and Growth Pact parameters.  
EPP approves enhanced Commission surveillance powers for budgetary plans, aligning with their commitment to structural reforms and debt reduction targets.  
EPP proposes reinforcing the review clause to mandate biannual assessments of economic partnership programmes' effectiveness in achieving deficit corrections.  
EPP endorses the rejection of mutualized debt instruments like eurobonds, emphasizing Treaty-compliant solutions that maintain national accountability under Article 125 TFEU.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of linking fiscal consolidation with growth-oriented policies, citing Latvia's successful austerity-to-growth model as validation.

EFD rejects centralized surveillance mechanisms as ineffective and treaty-overreaching, firmly doubting with EFD's principle of national fiscal sovereignty.
