It urged the Commission to revise the proposal to align with Parliament’s amendments, directed the Council to notify Parliament of any deviations from the approved text and to reconsult Parliament if intending substantial amendments, and emphasized adherence to prior resolutions on combating harmful tax practices. The resolution further instructed its President to formally transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural accountability and inter-institutional coordination.

title: Markets in financial instruments, market abuse and securities settlement: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 on markets in financial instruments, Regulation (EU) No 596/2014 on market abuse and Regulation (EU) No 909/2014 on improving securities settlement in the European Union and on central securities depositories as regards certain dates
background: The 2014 EU regulations on financial instruments, market abuse, and securities settlement faced implementation delays due to technical infrastructure challenges and deferred delegated acts, necessitating timeline adjustments. The Parliament will discuss amending application dates to ensure operational readiness while maintaining regulatory coherence across financial markets.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely upholds the extension of implementation deadlines to ensure technical readiness for enhanced investor protection, perfectly aligning with its commitment to stable financial markets.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on leveraging extended timelines to eliminate supervisory gaps and strengthen market abuse surveillance frameworks.  
EPP entirely upholds the creation of harmonized data systems through ESMA as critical for achieving transparency in securities settlements, advancing its priority of consumer-focused financial regulation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with measures preventing speculative bubbles through stringent disclosure requirements, reflecting its manifesto commitment to crisis-resilient economies.  
EPP entirely upholds transitional safeguards against emerging systemic risks in banking sectors, proposing strengthened monitoring mechanisms to address evolving market conditions.

EFDD rejects fundamentally the proposal's exemption of transparency requirements for banks' securities financing transactions (SFT) and EFP derivatives, which directly contradicts their demand for systemic accountability of financial institutions.  
EFDD opposes the issue's prioritization of capital markets union over banking separation measures, arguing this perpetuates systemic risks exposed during the 2008-2009 crisis rather than protecting taxpayers.  
EFDD condemns the extended deadlines as enabling opaque financial practices, asserting this aligns with Commissioner Hill's perceived deregulatory agenda favoring institutional interests over public safeguards.  
EFDD highlights the proposal's failure to address banks' reliance on public bailouts while shielding their high-risk transactions, a violation of their principle that "systemic actors must bear full transparency costs."  
This absolutely disapproves with EFDD's stance that EU legislation should prioritize real economy protections over financial market expansionism, as outlined in their 2016 anti-bailout manifesto.

GREEN_EFA completely disapproves the delay extension as it perpetuates unregulated speculation on food commodities, directly contradicting their mandate to prevent market-driven hunger crises.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the embedded exemptions reducing pre-trade transparency requirements, which violate their core principle of eliminating opaque financial practices.  
The proposal’s regulatory complexity – criticized as a vehicle for enforcement loopholes – conflicts with GREEN_EFA’s demand for simple, stringent rules to curb speculative derivatives trading.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s implicit prioritization of financial sector unpreparedness over urgent market abuse reforms outlined in their 2014 position.  
By enabling another year of unchecked commodity speculation, the timeline extension disregards GREEN_EFA’s documented warnings about derivatives markets dwarfing real economic activity.

ALDE firmly upholds the strategic delay to finalize workable MiFID/MiFIR rules, perfectly aligning with their commitment to precision in financial market governance.  
ALDE emphasizes that defining "research" with legal clarity is essential to prevent administrative burdens while ensuring investor-relevant transparency.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s balance between Timmermans’ better-regulation agenda and consumer protection priorities, advancing their vision of efficient yet accountable markets.  
ALDE highlights the necessity of ongoing dialogue with financial stakeholders and consumer groups to transform technical complexity into actionable safeguards.  
ALDE affirms that Einstein’s principle—valuing qualitative judgment over excessive metrics—resonates with their approach to proportionate, innovation-friendly regulation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2016)0057), submitted under Article 294(2) and Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and based on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report (A8-0125/2016). It formally adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to re-submit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text are planned. The Parliament also instructed its President to transmit its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment and transparency in the legislative process under the ordinary procedure.

title: Minimum loss coverage for non-performing exposures: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on amending Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 as regards minimum loss coverage for non-performing exposures
background: Persistently high non-performing loan levels in EU banks following the 2008 financial crisis, exceeding €800 billion, created financial stability risks and constrained credit availability. The European Commission proposed regulatory amendments addressing insufficient loss coverage practices. The Parliament will discuss establishing EU-wide minimum capital requirements for future non-performing exposures under the Capital Requirements Regulation.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the issue's approach to non-performing exposures for failing to address systemic governance failures and irresponsible fiscal policies that contradict EPP's emphasis on financial accountability.  
EPP opposes the proposal's lack of comprehensive diagnosis on the origins of non-performing loans, inconsistent with EPP's demand for rigorous root-cause analysis in financial regulation.  
EPP fully conflicts with the issue's framework as it overlooks critical aspects such as criminal exploitation of banking loopholes, which EPP prioritizes in anti-terrorism and financial crime agendas.  
EPP criticizes the issue for neglecting long-term fiscal discipline measures, a cornerstone of EPP's economic policy, thereby risking superficial solutions to deep-seated financial vulnerabilities.  
EPP disputes the proposal's alignment with sustainable growth principles, arguing it fails to enforce the stringent public finance management EPP deems essential for true economic recovery.

ENF supports the issue’s shift of bank rescue liability from taxpayers but advises stricter loss coverage thresholds in Annex II to mitigate systemic instability risks warned by the Dutch WRR.  
ENF recommends extending Article 4(2) implementation timelines to allow phased alignment with national risk reduction frameworks, addressing concerns over abrupt harmonization.  
ENF cautions against excessive uniformity in capital market rules and proposes inserting a five-year ECB stability assessment clause to monitor financial interconnectedness risks.  
ENF advises amending recital 12 to explicitly reference member states’ discretion in applying liquidity support mechanisms, reflecting varied readiness for centralized guarantees.  
ENF highlights the need for proportionality in exposure classification criteria to prevent destabilizing smaller financial institutions, urging tailored thresholds in Article 7(1a).

ECR rejects the issue's failure to address €600 billion in existing non-performing exposures, creating only future provisions that ignore current systemic risks.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the accelerated foreclosure processes enabled by the regulation, demanding immediate protection for primary residences.  
ECR condemns the proposal's three-year implementation delay as insufficient to resolve banking instability, requiring immediate write-downs.  
ECR highlights contradictions with subsidiarity principles by ignoring national civil law variations in debt recovery timelines.  
ECR demands creation of state-backed borrower protection funds to purchase NPLs at fair value rather than enabling vulture investors.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the issue’s procedural accountability measures, aligning with their commitment to preventing reckless financial sector practices that endanger citizens’ housing rights.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening consumer protections in Article 4 to explicitly prohibit bulk sales of household mortgages to unregulated entities, addressing Ireland’s crisis-driven lessons.  
GUE_NGL applauds the emphasis on ECB-aligned harmonization as advancing their manifesto goals for cross-border banking transparency and debtor safeguards.  
GUE_NGL urges amendments to extend transparency rules to shadow banking recipients of non-performing exposures, closing regulatory loopholes cited in the Irish example.  
GUE_NGL highlights the need to accelerate risk-sharing mechanisms alongside loss coverage to prevent systemic fragmentation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0134) concerning measures under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aimed at harmonizing member state laws to ensure the functioning of the internal market. It adopted its first-reading stance as outlined in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report (A8-0440/2018), emphasizing the need for legal coherence and alignment with input from the European Central Bank and the European Economic and Social Committee. The resolution urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially alters or replaces its original proposal, ensuring legislative transparency and procedural accountability. Additionally, Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing inter-institutional dialogue and adherence to EU legislative protocols.

title: Green Paper on Retail Financial Services: REPORT on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services
background: The European Union's retail financial services market faced fragmentation, low cross-border activity, and varying consumer protections, exacerbated by digitalization and fintech growth. The European Commission's 2015 Green Paper highlighted barriers to integration and competition. The Parliament will discuss improving the single market for retail financial services, addressing market fragmentation, consumer protection, and digital innovation.

stances.stance:
EFDD rejects the issue's approach to cross-border financial services as absolutely challengeing with their opposition to EU regulatory overreach post-Brexit.  
EFDD opposes harmonized EU comparison tools and dispute mechanisms, viewing them as centralizing frameworks that undermine national sovereignty in financial markets.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of consumer pragmatism by prioritizing geo-blocking elimination over practical redress complexities in cross-border transactions.  
EFDD condemns the issue's implicit threat to restrict UK-based financial services access, which contradicts their stance on preserving consumer choice beyond EU borders.  
The emphasis on EU-wide digital ID interoperability and standardized documents disregards EFDD's warnings about bureaucratic opacity in high-value financial products.

ALDE absolutely sanctions the issue’s emphasis on fostering fintech innovation and digital infrastructure as critical to achieving EU-wide economic competitiveness, perfectly aligning with ALDE’s commitment to market-driven technological advancement.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for harmonized consumer protection frameworks and standardized product comparability, which directly advances ALDE’s priorities of eliminating cross-border fragmentation and empowering retail investors.  
ALDE highlights the necessity of ensuring a level playing field for smaller financial institutions through rigorous enforcement of proportionality in capital requirements, thereby strengthening the issue’s goal of fair cross-border competition.  
ALDE fully supports the push for interoperable digital ID systems and innovation-friendly regulation, recognizing these as essential to unlocking consumer access and systemic efficiency in line with ALDE’s digital single market agenda.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgency of addressing disproportionate return-on-equity demands by banks as part of enhancing regulatory neutrality, reinforcing the issue’s focus on preventing market distortions and safeguarding financial stability.

SD absolutely promotes the issue’s emphasis on creating a pan-European savings product to mobilize private savings for green investments, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to sustainable finance and long-term ecological transition.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand for rigorous consumer protection enforcement, particularly through standardized PRIIPs KIDs and crackdowns on geo-blocking, reflecting SD’s unwavering focus on transparency and fairness in financial markets.  
SD highlights the critical need to strengthen ESMA and national authorities’ oversight of FinTech platforms to combat fraudulent practices, enhancing the issue’s digital innovation safeguards while preserving market trust.  
SD fully supports harmonizing cross-border access to financial services through EU-wide comparison tools and portable dispute mechanisms, advancing SD’s priority of eliminating administrative barriers to financial inclusion.  
SD underscores the urgency of integrating robust data privacy protections with digital financial tools like robo-advisors, ensuring innovation aligns with SD’s principles of consumer security and ethical fintech governance.

GUE/NGL rejects fundamentally the issue’s market liberalization agenda as a vehicle for financial oligopolies and erosion of public sovereignty.  
GUE/NGL opposes the promotion of digitalization frameworks that prioritize cost-cutting over worker protections, exacerbating labor precarization in the financial sector.  
This proposal conflicts irreconcilably with GUE/NGL’s demand for robust public banking systems to guarantee universal access to essential services without exploitative fees.  
The issue’s alignment with Capital Markets Union objectives perpetuates harmful privatization, directly contradicting GUE/NGL’s anti-austerity principles.  
GUE/NGL condemns the failure to address corporate concentration risks, enabling pan-European banking monopolies that displace local institutions and deepen inequality.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the fragmented and underdeveloped EU retail financial services market, emphasizing the need to enhance cross-border competition, consumer protection, and digital innovation while addressing risks such as financial exclusion, data security, and unfair practices. It highlighted the low cross-border transaction rates, significant price disparities (e.g., vehicle insurance costs varying hundreds of times between Member States), and Europe’s lagging fintech funding (USD 348 million in Q1 2016 vs. USD 1.8 billion in North America and USD 2.6 billion in China). The resolution called for stricter enforcement of existing legislation (e.g., PSD2, MiFID II, Mortgage Credit Directive), simplified product comparability through standardized documents (e.g., PRIIPs KIDs), and measures to eliminate unjustified geo-blocking and residence-based discrimination. It urged the Commission to promote digital ID interoperability, create EU-wide comparison tools and dispute resolution mechanisms, and ensure non-digital access to essential services to prevent exclusion. Other priorities included harmonizing insurance guarantee schemes, improving financial literacy, restricting risky retail investor products (e.g., bail-in instruments), and fostering fintech growth via regulatory neutrality and innovation-friendly frameworks. Long-term goals included cross-border portability of pensions and insurance, addressing currency exchange risks, and aligning retail financial services with broader EU agendas like the Capital Markets Union and Sustainable Finance.

title: International Accounting Standards (IAS) evaluation: REPORT on International Accounting Standards (IAS) evaluation and the activities of the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) Foundation, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group (EFRAG) and the Public Interest Oversight Board (PIOB)
background: The EU adopted International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) in 2002 to harmonize financial reporting, with post-2008 crisis reforms highlighting gaps in transparency, procyclicality, and governance. Ongoing evaluations addressed IFRS alignment with EU directives, stakeholder concerns on financial stability, and institutional roles of EFRAG, IFRS Foundation, and PIOB. The Parliament will discuss IFRS effectiveness, governance, and compliance with EU accounting principles.

stances.stance:
EPP fully promotes the issue's emphasis on developing simplified EU-wide accounting standards for SMEs, perfectly aligning with our commitment to enhancing cross-border business mobility and capital market accessibility.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for full implementation of IFRS across all Member States, recognizing this as essential for maintaining the integrity of the Single Market and investor confidence.  
EPP strongly advocates the issue's push for common implementation guidelines, viewing this as a critical enhancement opportunity to eliminate fragmentation in financial reporting practices.  
EPP applauds the focus on prudence and stewardship in accounting frameworks, which directly advances our priority of ensuring market stability through reliable financial disclosures.  
EPP fully promotes the integration of climate-related financial risks into accounting standards, consistent with our 2023 manifesto commitments to sustainable economic governance.

EFDD entirely doubts mandatory country-by-country reporting requirements as a one-size-fits-all solution conflicting with national sovereignty principles.  
EFDD rejects the issue's standardized accounting frameworks for failing to address critical disparities among EU member states' legal and fiscal systems.  
EFDD argues the proposal's tax avoidance measures overlook legitimate financial planning distinctions, conflating lawful optimization with illicit evasion.  
EFDD contends the issue's EU-centric reporting mandates undermine subsidiarity by imposing uniform rules across 28 distinct jurisdictions.  
EFDD opposes the issue's complexity-driven reforms as incompatible with EFDD's advocacy for decentralized, context-sensitive regulatory approaches.

GREEN_EFA totally sanctions the issue’s demand for governance reforms at the IFRS Foundation, perfectly aligning with their unwavering commitment to transparency and democratic accountability in financial governance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the critique of IFRS 9’s expected loss model, emphasizing that prudent accounting practices must prioritize long-term stability over short-term speculative gains as core to their ecological stewardship principles.  
GREEN_EFA totally sanctions mandatory country-by-country reporting requirements, recognizing this as a critical tool to combat corporate tax avoidance and advance fiscal justice—a pillar of their economic policy agenda.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the push for European Public Sector Accounting Standards (EPSAS), which directly advances their vision of transparent public finance management essential for green transition investments.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that integrating climate-related financial risks into accounting frameworks effectively advances their manifesto pledge to embed planetary boundaries in all economic decision-making.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s conflation of accounting reforms with crisis issue, completely condemning with their position that systemic financial speculation requires public control, not technical adjustments.  
GUE_NGL opposes the reliance on IFRS governance tweaks, arguing this overlooks the imperative to dismantle oligarchic power structures dominating EU policymaking.  
GUE_NGL criticizes the issue’s emphasis on prudence and stewardship frameworks as inadequate substitutes for binding capital controls and anti-speculation measures.  
GUE_NGL asserts that macroeconomic impact assessments proposed fail to address the root crisis driver: profit-driven financialization opposing public interest governance.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s avoidance of explicit demands for nationalization or democratic oversight mechanisms to curb corporate tax avoidance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the alignment of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) with EU legal frameworks, emphasizing the need for standards to serve the public good, ensure financial stability, and adhere to the "true and fair view" principle enshrined in EU directives. It highlighted the EU’s 14% financial contribution to the IFRS Foundation, urging governance reforms to enhance transparency, prevent conflicts of interest, and broaden representation, including finance ministries and consumer agencies. The resolution stressed the importance of prudence, reliability, and stewardship in accounting, critiquing IFRS 9’s expected loss model for potential impacts on long-term investments and insurance sectors, while calling for simplified standards, robust macroeconomic impact assessments, and improved SME representation. It advocated mandatory country-by-country reporting to combat tax avoidance, supported the development of European Public Sector Accounting Standards (EPSAS) for public finance transparency, and urged stricter enforcement of ESMA guidelines across Member States. The Parliament called on the Commission to formalize EFRAG’s role in evaluating standards’ financial stability implications, address IASB governance deficiencies, and ensure systematic alignment of IFRS with EU objectives, including capital maintenance rules and dividend distribution safeguards under the Accounting Directive. Additionally, it pushed for reforms to reduce IFRS complexity, enhance stakeholder involvement, and integrate climate-related financial risks into accounting frameworks.

title: Rates of value added tax: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2006/112/EC as regards rates of value added tax
background: For over 25 years, the EU's temporary cross-border VAT system faced fragmentation, legal inconsistencies, and significant fraud, with an annual €150 billion VAT gap. Persistent administrative burdens and divergent national rules hindered intra-EU trade. The Parliament will discuss reforming VAT rates and rules to address fraud and harmonize the single market framework.

stances.stance:
EFDD totally conflicts the issue's VAT harmonization as it contradicts the principle of tax competition and national sovereignty.  
EFDD rejects the EU's centralized tax approach, advocating instead for localized sales taxes to foster business growth and employment.  
The proposal overlooks EFDD's demand to abolish VAT post-Brexit and adopt a simplified 6% sales tax, leaving wealth with citizens.  
EFDD condemns the issue's alignment with Article 113 TFEU, viewing it as an undemocratic erosion of member states' fiscal autonomy.  
EFDD asserts that VAT complexity stifles small businesses, urging the EU to prioritize deregulation over revenue preservation.

ENF completely condemns the VAT harmonization framework as contradicting their core principle of national fiscal sovereignty, rejecting EU-level rate standardization.  
ENF condemns the 25% VAT ceiling for enabling excessive taxation that "saccheggia" Italian families, demanding full retention of national rate-setting autonomy.  
ENF rejects the issue's failure to address wasteful EU expenditures like dual parliamentary seats funded by Italian VAT contributions, calling it fiscal exploitation.  
ENF challenges the Certified Taxable Person mechanism as inadequate against fraud, insisting on complete anti-evasion protocols before considering system changes.  
ENF asserts the weighted average 12% rate requirement imposes covert harmonization, violating subsidiarity despite superficial flexibility claims.

GREEN_EFA absolutely sanctions the harmonized VAT framework as perfectly aligning with their commitment to combating fraud and ensuring fiscal equity across borders.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the issue’s unified tax regime, recognizing its critical role in advancing European integration and reducing administrative fragmentation.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the flexibility for Member States to apply reduced rates, reinforcing their support for subsidiarity and incentivizing climate-friendly policies.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the urgency of post-Brexit VAT clarity as an enhancement opportunity to protect businesses and maintain anti-fraud cooperation.  
GREEN_FA perfectly aligns with the issue’s focus on procedural transparency, ensuring democratic accountability in cross-border taxation reforms.

ALDE totally advocates the 15-25% VAT rate framework as perfectly aligning with their commitment to combatting fraud through simplified fiscal architecture while preserving member state flexibility.  
ALDE strongly promotes the certified taxable persons system, recognizing its transformative potential for reducing cross-border transaction costs in line with single market efficiency goals.  
ALDE applauds the multilingual VAT portal proposal as effectively advancing digital governance priorities and consumer transparency across EU jurisdictions.  
ALDE confirms reduced VAT rates for socio-environmental sectors like equine therapy align with treaty provisions, enabling targeted support for rural employment and healthcare innovation.  
ALDE emphasizes the destination principle's critical anti-fraud merits, noting its consistency with their longstanding advocacy for closing €50 billion annual VAT loopholes.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by approving the Commission’s 2018 proposal on taxation policy (COM(2018)0020) as amended, emphasizing alignment with Article 113 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It called on the Commission to revise its proposal under Article 293(2) to reflect Parliament’s amendments and urged the Council to notify Parliament if deviating from the approved text. Parliament further requested the Council to reconsult it if intending substantial changes to the proposal, ensuring legislative coherence. The resolution instructed the Parliament’s President to transmit its stance to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and inter-institutional dialogue while focusing on harmonizing taxation rules across member states.

title: Indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts
background: Scandals involving benchmark manipulation (LIBOR, forex) led to significant fines and eroded trust in financial markets, prompting the European Commission to propose regulations addressing governance and transparency vulnerabilities. The Parliament will discuss establishing regulatory standards for financial benchmarks to ensure integrity and prevent market abuse.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely agrees the balanced regulatory framework for critical benchmarks, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to financial market stability through proportionate governance and ESMA coordination.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s third-country regime improvements, which reinforce EPP’s priority of harmonizing EU standards while maintaining global competitiveness in benchmark administration.  
EPP absolutely agrees the enhanced transparency mechanisms for non-critical indices, advancing EPP’s longstanding goal of restoring investor confidence without imposing disproportionate burdens on SMEs.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s proportionality principle, which reflects EPP’s strategy to prioritize rigorous oversight for systemic benchmarks while enabling innovation in niche financial instruments.  
EPP absolutely agrees the consumer protection provisions, recognizing their critical role in fulfilling EPP’s manifesto pledge to eliminate market manipulation risks through auditable benchmark methodologies.

GREEN_EFA totally disputes with the issue’s exemption of non-critical benchmarks, enabling continued industry manipulation without EU-wide accountability.  
GREEN_EFA rejects delegating critical benchmark definitions to member states, creating regulatory arbitrage opportunities that undermine market integrity.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the insufficient ESMA oversight provisions, which fail to prevent fragmented enforcement and lax penalties for financial misconduct.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue’s tolerance of tax-deductible fines for benchmark manipulation, effectively socializing the cost of corporate fraud.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal’s regression from stricter national standards like the UK’s, contradicting their demand for harmonized, robust financial safeguards.

ALDE strongly supports the enhanced supervisory role of ESMA in overseeing critical benchmarks, aligning with their commitment to a resilient single financial market and robust oversight mechanisms.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s balanced integration of qualitative criteria for defining critical benchmarks, ensuring adaptability to systemic risks beyond narrow quantitative thresholds.  
ALDE proposes reinforcing ESMA’s budgetary autonomy to safeguard its capacity for rigorous supervision, framing this as an enhancement opportunity rather than opposition to the framework.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on consumer protection and market integrity, particularly in addressing historical abuses like the Swiss franc loan crisis, reflecting their manifesto-driven priorities.  
ALDE commends the pragmatic collaboration across political groups to achieve a harmonized regulatory approach, advancing transparency and proportionality in benchmark governance.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue for failing to prohibit abusive indices like IRPH, which exploits low-income families through non-transparent calculation methods entirely rejecting with GUE/NGL's anti-austerity principles.  
GUE/NGL opposes the regulation’s allowance of non-market-driven benchmarks, highlighting how IRPH’s detachment from supply-demand dynamics perpetuates systemic financial injustice against vulnerable households.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of bank accountability, as evidenced by unresolved historical exploitation cases like Deutsche Bank’s role in Greece’s debt crisis, which GUE/NGL condemns as institutionalized predation.  
GUE/NGL demands explicit bans on indices lacking public data disclosure, noting the IRPH’s secrecy directly contradicts the regulation’s purported transparency goals and enables ongoing borrower exploitation.  
This framework entirely rejects with GUE/NGL’s demand for debt justice, ignoring proven harm where families repay 33 billion euros beyond borrowed sums due to predatory financial instruments left unaddressed.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s legislative proposal COM(2013)0641 under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, addressing the UK House of Commons’ reasoned opinion contesting compliance with subsidiarity under Protocol No 2. It incorporated the European Central Bank’s January 2014 opinion and the European Economic and Social Committee’s January 2014 input, alongside the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs’ report (A8-0131/2015) and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy’s opinion. The resolution formally adopted Parliament’s stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments, and directed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with procedural and substantive legislative requirements.

title: Insurance mediation: SUPPLEMENTARY REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on insurance mediation (recast)
background: The European Commission proposed recasting the 2002 Insurance Mediation Directive in 2012 to address fragmented national regulations and consumer protection gaps in cross-border insurance markets amid post-2008 financial reforms. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing EU insurance distribution rules to strengthen consumer safeguards and market integration.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally endorses the harmonized consumer protection standards across insurance distribution channels, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to transparent EU-wide financial markets.  
EPP strongly sanctions maintaining national flexibility in commission structures while enhancing transparency requirements, effectively advancing fair competition between distribution models.  
EPP applauds the proportionality principle exempting micro-insurance products, which preserves consumer convenience and market accessibility as prioritized in EPP's SME agenda.  
EPP emphasizes rigorous EIOPA oversight to prevent regulatory arbitrage opportunities, reinforcing Parliament's role in safeguarding legislative intent.  
EPP welcomes the standardized pre-contract information sheet as a milestone achievement in enabling cross-border product comparability, fulfilling EPP's consumer empowerment objectives.

EFDD rejects the issue's single-market harmonization approach as perpetuating systemic bias toward large insurers, absolutely conflicting with EFDD's defense of SME competitiveness.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as disproportionate compliance costs for smaller intermediaries, directly contradicting EFDD's principles of regulatory proportionality.  
EFDD opposes the codification of cross-selling rules as entrenching compliance advantages for multinational corporations over local market participants.  
This directive exemplifies EU overreach into member state regulatory autonomy, a core EFDD concern given divergent national insurance market structures.  
The issue's failure to exempt micro-enterprises from standardized requirements undermines consumer choice and market diversity, key EFDD policy priorities.

SD absolutely advocates the issue's harmonization of cross-selling rules, perfectly aligning with S&D's commitment to preventing consumer coercion in bundled insurance products while preserving market integration.  
SD perfectly supports the mandatory consent requirements for post-contract suitability statements, affirming S&D's priority of empowering informed consumer decision-making through transparent disclosure practices.  
SD absolutely advocates the issue's preservation of member states' enforcement powers, effectively advancing S&D's demand for robust anti-circumvention measures and non-discriminatory market oversight.  
SD perfectly aligns with the directive's professional training mandates, recognizing their critical role in fulfilling S&D's manifesto pledge for competency-driven financial services.  
SD fully supports the codification approach as a strategic reinforcement of existing consumer protections, consistent with S&D's decade-long advocacy against remuneration-driven conflicts in insurance distribution.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to prohibit opaque commission structures for insurance brokers, which fundamentally doubts with their demand for full financial transparency in consumer markets.  
GUE_NGL opposes the limited scope of transparency requirements as inconsistent with their principle of universal market accountability, noting the issue excludes critical insurance products from disclosure rules.  
GUE_NGL condemns the directive’s implicit alignment with concentrated banking interests, arguing it overlooks systemic power imbalances that enable corporate exploitation of consumers.  
GUE_NGL opposes permitting insurers to pay commissions to brokers, warning this perpetuates biased advice and directly contradicts their manifesto commitment to eradicate conflicts of interest in financial services.  
GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s inadequate safeguards against regulatory arbitrage, emphasizing it fails to empower member states to fully dismantle cross-border predatory practices by dominant market actors.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined measures regarding the regulation of insurance distribution, emphasizing the balance between consumer protection and market efficiency. The resolution highlighted that cross-selling practices by insurance distributors, while potentially beneficial, risk undermining consumer interests, and clarified that the Directive should not prohibit multi-risk insurance policies but must align with existing Union legislation on cross-selling. It affirmed member states' authority to penalize irregularities and enforce non-discriminatory measures to protect consumers, including restricting insurance intermediaries from operating in their territories if activities are directed primarily to circumvent local regulations, with provisions for coordination through EIOPA to resolve disputes between national authorities. The resolution mandated that customers must consent to receiving post-contract suitability statements and be offered the option to delay contract conclusion to review such statements in advance, ensuring informed decision-making. It endorsed the Commission’s proposal as a codification of existing texts without substantive changes, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if significant amendments are proposed.

title: Rules against certain tax avoidance practices: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive laying down rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market
background: Recent multinational tax avoidance scandals, including LuxLeaks and Panama Papers, exposed profit-shifting to low-tax jurisdictions, undermining EU tax revenues and market fairness. Divergent national tax rules created loopholes exploited by corporations. The Parliament will discuss proposed EU-wide anti-tax avoidance rules to harmonize corporate taxation and protect the internal market's integrity.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly upholds the issue's focus on combating aggressive tax planning through binding EU-wide measures, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to ethical market economies and fair competition.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly reference OECD BEPS guidelines, ensuring global alignment while maintaining the issue's core anti-avoidance mechanisms.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on production-linked investments over fiscal engineering, which directly advances ALDE's priority of redirecting capital toward innovation and SME growth.  
ALDE urges inclusion of regional tax authorities with fiscal autonomy in coordination mechanisms, as exemplified by the Basque and Navarre systems, to strengthen anti-avoidance enforcement.  
ALDE applauds the issue's alignment with their manifesto demand for profit taxation at source, particularly supporting the provisions against profit-shifting to low-tax jurisdictions.

SD fully sanctions the issue's strengthened "switch-over" clause to prevent unfair tax competition on incoming profits, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to equitable corporate taxation.  
SD perfectly aligns with imposing exit taxation mechanisms to address profit shifting outside the EU, advancing SD's priority of closing double non-taxation loopholes.  
SD fully sanctions the harmonized definition of "permanent establishment" to combat digital economy tax avoidance, effectively advancing legal clarity against entities like Booking.com.  
SD perfectly supports mandatory substance requirements for intra-group loans, aligning with SD's manifesto goal of eliminating artificial interest deduction schemes used by multinationals.  
SD fully sanctions cross-border transparency obligations for trusts and foundations, perfectly matching SD's 2023 agenda to expose shell company structures within the EU.

ECR rejects the issue's focus on harmonizing corporate tax rates as a direct violation of member states' fiscal sovereignty.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the proposed 20% cap on interest deductibility, arguing it creates double taxation and penalizes legitimate business investments.  
This proposal conflicts with ECR's principle that tax competition preserves economic dynamism, overlooking how low corporate taxes attract international capital to Europe.  
ECR condemns the push for an EU-wide tax identification system, viewing it as bureaucratic overreach inconsistent with subsidiarity requirements.  
The issue's approach to profit allocation fails to address aggressive tax planning effectively while imposing centralized solutions ECR deems hostile to SME competitiveness.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the issue's failure to mandate binding withholding taxes on financial flows to tax havens, allowing profits to continue leaving the EU untaxed.  
GUE_NGL opposes the exemption for "active business" income in tax havens, which perpetuates loopholes enabling corporations like McDonald's to avoid fair taxation on real economic activities.  
GUE_NGL condemns the weakened interest barrier rules compared to both the Commission's original proposal and U.S. standards, calling this a gift to profit-shifting multinationals through artificial interest deductions.  
GUE_NGL denounces the absence of a phase-out requirement for patent boxes, directly contradicting OECD guidance and enabling race-to-the-bottom corporate tax avoidance under the guise of supporting innovation.  
GUE_NGL declares the issue's reliance on tax haven blacklists instead of automatic sanctions fully disputes with their demand for immediate asset freezes and trade restrictions against complicit jurisdictions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2016 legislative proposal (COM(2016)0026) under Article 115 TFEU, approving the amended proposal and urging the Commission to revise its text accordingly under Article 293(2) TFEU. It emphasized procedural safeguards, demanding the Council inform Parliament of any deviations from the approved text and reconsult Parliament if proposing substantial amendments. The resolution highlighted subsidiarity concerns raised by the Maltese and Swedish parliaments, which argued the proposal overstepped EU competence. Parliament instructed its President to transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing legislative oversight and inter-institutional accountability while addressing the proposal’s alignment with EU treaty principles.

title: Sovereign bond-backed securities: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on sovereign bond-backed securities
background: Following the eurozone sovereign debt crisis, which exposed vulnerabilities in bank-sovereign linkages and prompted post-crisis financial reforms, the European Parliament will discuss regulatory adjustments to enable sovereign bond-backed securities as private instruments for diversifying bank sovereign exposures and enhancing financial stability.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA totally supports the establishment of a robust SBBS regulatory framework as a critical step toward mitigating systemic risks, aligning perfectly with its commitment to financial stability and cross-border investment transparency.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of ESMA’s liquidity monitoring mandate and the European Systemic Risk Board’s macroprudential oversight role, which effectively advance its priority of preventing market fragmentation and ensuring accountable financial innovation.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue’s tranche structure as a prudent risk-allocation mechanism, consistent with its advocacy for layered investor protections and equitable loss-absorption hierarchies.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the continued necessity for complementary fiscal tools like eurobonds, framing this issue as a provisional advancement rather than a substitute for deeper structural reforms to EU fiscal governance.  
 While GREEN_EFA’s critique of SBBS as insufficient to resolve the eurozone’s fiscal design flaws is noted, this is contextualized as future advocacy rather than opposition to the current framework.

ALDE strongly accepts the establishment of SBBS as a vital instrument to fortify the euro and promote cross-border financial integration, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to a resilient and unified European economy.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s focus on risk diversification and debt alleviation for member states, effectively advancing ALDE’s priority of fostering economic solidarity while maintaining fiscal sustainability.  
ALDE emphasizes the framework’s explicit inclusion of all Eurogroup states without marginalization, reflecting their core principle of equitable integration across the EU.  
ALDE proposes enhancing ESMA’s public certification list by adding periodic market feedback mechanisms to ensure ongoing transparency, without opposing the core compliance structure in Articles 4–6.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s potential to indirectly bolster social policies through improved sovereign debt management, consistent with their advocacy for harmonizing economic stability and social equity.

ECR rejects the SBBS framework as fundamentally disputeing with their stance against synthetic financial instruments that amplify systemic risks, referencing Article 4-6 transparency measures as insufficient to prevent crisis contagion.  
ECR opposes the tranche structure in principle, arguing it replicates the "toxic" securitization models that exacerbated the 2008 U.S. financial collapse, contrary to their commitment to straightforward banking reforms.  
ECR highlights the issue's failure to address structural Eurozone imbalances, noting how similar mechanisms like Greece’s PSI disproportionately harmed citizens while shielding ECB holdings.  
ECR contends ESMA certification (Articles 7-8) creates a false veneer of safety for SBBS, overlooking critical aspects like correlation risks during sovereign debt crises.  
ECR demands Eurozone architectural reforms prioritizing citizen protections over bank-centric solutions, dismissing SBBS as incompatible with their vision of a non-hierarchical monetary union.

GUE_NGL rejects the SBBS framework as dangerously replicating the financialization strategies that caused the 2008 crisis, citing their inherent instability during market stress.  
GUE_NGL completely conflicts treating sovereign debt as a speculative asset class, arguing this distracts from needed ECB guarantees on member-state bonds.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue’s failure to address structural Eurozone imbalances like Germany’s export surplus policies harming peripheral economies.  
GUE_NGL condemns SBBS as a technical fix ignoring the necessity of public investment mechanisms for regional economic convergence.  
GUE_NGL demands genuine EU bonds with joint liability instead of layered risk tranches that perpetuate austerity-driven status quo.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the establishment of a regulatory framework for sovereign bond-backed securities (SBBS) to enhance financial stability and risk diversification, defining SBBS as euro-denominated instruments linked to a portfolio of sovereign bonds issued by Member States with maturities of at least one year. It mandated that SBBS must comply with Articles 4, 5, and 6, ensuring transparency, risk disclosure, and structural requirements, while special purpose entities (SPEs) issuing SBBS must adhere to Articles 7 and 8, governing their operational and governance standards. The resolution introduced a tranche structure (senior, subordinated, junior) to prioritize loss absorption, with junior tranches bearing losses first. It required the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) to certify SBBS compliance and maintain a public list of approved products, emphasizing that only certified SBBS could be marketed. The framework aimed to mitigate systemic risks, promote cross-border investment, and standardize SBBS issuance, while clarifying definitions of key terms like "competent authority" and "original purchaser" to ensure legal certainty and alignment with existing EU financial regulations.

title: Sustainable finance: REPORT on sustainable finance
background: The European Union has engaged in international climate agreements and financial reforms, with reports highlighting funding gaps and risks from carbon-intensive assets. Existing frameworks address non-financial disclosures and sustainable investment challenges. The Parliament will discuss integrating environmental, social, and governance factors into EU financial systems to align with sustainability goals.

stances.stance:
ENF rejects the mandatory ESG disclosure frameworks as interventionist market distortions conflicting with free-market principles.  
ENF opposes political interference in creditworthiness assessments of green investments, citing Dr. König’s warnings about sustainability risks and market bubbles.  
ENF fully challenges with imposing Germany’s Energiewende as a binding EU model, arguing it disregards national sovereignty and market diversity.  
ENF criticizes public-sector green bonds and subsidies as fiscally irresponsible interventions that contradict fiscal conservatism.  
ENF highlights the issue’s failure to address systemic risks of “green” asset overvaluation, aligning with warnings from the Systemic Risk Board.

GREEN_EFA entirely approves the issue's demand for mandatory EU-wide due diligence legislation, as this perfectly aligns with their commitment to eradicating corporate opacity in supply chains and rewarding truly sustainable business models.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s systemic emphasis on carbon divestment and green finance innovation, viewing radical policy creativity as non-negotiable for survival amid climate collapse.  
GREEN_EFA entirely approves the proposed EU sustainability taxonomy and Green Finance Mark, recognizing these frameworks as essential to standardizing ESG accountability and accelerating global leadership in ethical capital allocation.  
GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s directive for public institutions like the EIB to phase out fossil fuel subsidies, stressing that Paris Agreement alignment must override legacy investment biases.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s focus on closing the social infrastructure gap through green FinTech solutions, seeing this as critical to democratizing sustainable finance for SMEs and marginalized communities.

ECR firmly againsts the issue's framework for failing to rectify systemic financial inequities within EU mechanisms.  
ECR rejects the proposed ESG integration as incompatible with addressing immediate disparities in quantitative easing access for member states like Greece.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of fair capital allocation by maintaining exclusionary practices in ECB bond-buying programs.  
ECR condemns the issue's silence on reconciling national central bank investments with bloc-wide monetary policy exclusions.  
This approach conflicts with ECR's principle of equitable treatment among EU nations in foundational financial instruments.

GUE_NGL strongly promotes the mandatory integration of ESG factors into financial regulations, particularly climate risk disclosures, as this aligns perfectly with their commitment to systemic economic justice and corporate accountability.  

GUE_NGL approves the EU sustainability taxonomy framework but proposes amending Section 2(b) to explicitly include social safeguards ensuring worker protections during transitions out of carbon-intensive industries.  

GUE_NGL absolutely accepts the phase-out of fossil fuel subsidies and stranded asset risk disclosures, a policy that effectively advances their decades-long advocacy for public-led energy democracy.  

GUE_NGL strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on closing the social infrastructure gap, urging binding targets for affordable housing and healthcare access through public development banks.  

GUE_NGL applauds the Green Finance Mark proposal as critical to combating greenwashing, aligning with their 2023 manifesto demand for strict labeling of corporate sustainability claims.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about aligning financial systems with sustainability goals, emphasizing the urgent need to address a EUR 180 billion annual funding gap for EU decarbonization and other Sustainable Development Goals. It highlighted systemic risks from stranded fossil fuel assets, citing USD 1.1-2 trillion in at-risk investments and Europe’s 45% investor exposure to carbon-intensive sectors, alongside insufficient green infrastructure (less than 1% globally). The resolution called for integrating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors into financial regulations, including mandatory disclosure frameworks, fiduciary duties, and prudential rules to reflect climate risks. It urged the establishment of an EU sustainability taxonomy by 2019 to standardize ESG metrics, a "Green Finance Mark" for high-standard sustainable products, and amendments to directives (e.g., Non-Financial Reporting, Shareholder Rights) to enforce ESG transparency. The Parliament stressed the role of public institutions like the EIB and ECB in prioritizing Paris Agreement-aligned investments, phasing out fossil fuel subsidies, and issuing green bonds, while advocating for "carbon stress tests" to assess financial stability risks. It also emphasized closing the EUR 1.5 trillion social infrastructure gap, promoting green FinTech for SMEs, and ensuring EU spending coherence with climate goals, including 20% of the budget for climate action. International alignment with UN SDGs, OECD guidelines, and G20 commitments was underscored, alongside reforms to credit rating methodologies and stewardship requirements to foster long-term, sustainable capital allocation.

title: Taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments: repealing the Savings Directive: REPORT on the proposal for a Council directive repealing Council Directive 2003/48/EC
background: The EU Savings Taxation Directive (2003/48/EC) established cross-border interest payment reporting to combat tax evasion but faced limitations in scope and effectiveness. Following OECD global transparency standards and the 2014 Administrative Cooperation Directive introducing broader automatic information exchange, discrepancies emerged between legacy frameworks and modern requirements. The Parliament will discuss repealing the Savings Directive to align with updated multilateral tax transparency mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP completely approves the repeal of the Savings Directive as it perfectly aligns with the party's commitment to combat tax evasion through enhanced transparency frameworks.  
EPP emphasizes that the mandatory automatic exchange of tax rulings under the new Directive on Administrative Cooperation creates a more effective mechanism than the Savings Directive, ensuring fair taxation where economic activity occurs.  
EPP underscores the critical need for continuous Commission oversight to prevent information gaps between member states, proposing reinforced audit protocols to maintain data integrity during the transition.  
EPP strongly promotes cross-border tax ruling transparency as a direct response to LuxLeaks, aligning with its 2019 manifesto pledge to eliminate distortionary fiscal practices in the single market.  
EPP perfectly aligns with Parliament's demand for Council reconsultation requirements, viewing this as essential to uphold democratic accountability in tax governance under TFEU Article 293(2).

EFDD rejects the proposal as fundamentally inadequate in addressing systemic tax inequities enabled by EU member states.  
EFDD opposes the Council's opaque agreement for failing to implement public access to tax documents, contradicting transparency principles.  
EFDD condemns the issue’s reliance on EU mechanisms, which perpetuate tax sovereignty erosion and multinational exploitation.  
EFDD highlights the proposal’s inconsistency with national fiscal autonomy, echoing Patrick O’Flynn’s argument that EU structures incentivize harmful tax competition.  
EFDD asserts that historical tax abuses remain unaddressed, mirroring Marco Zanni’s critique of retroactive loopholes in information-sharing rules.

SD fundamentally accepts the issue's mandate for comprehensive transparency in tax rulings, ensuring all multinational agreements are subject to EU-wide scrutiny without temporal or jurisdictional limitations.  
SD perfectly aligns with the retroactive application of information exchange requirements spanning ten years, crucial for addressing historical tax avoidance practices exposed in recent state aid cases.  
SD fully supports strengthening the European Commission's enforcement capacity through real-time access to all cross-border tax rulings, rejecting Council attempts to limit oversight scope.  
SD endorses binding sanctions for non-compliant member states, aligning with Parliament's amendments to prevent procedural delays in combating harmful tax competition.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's integration of a European taxpayer identification system, enhancing cross-border audit capabilities to combat evasion.

GUE_NGL absolutely sanctions the issue's mandate for automatic fiscal information exchange between member states, as this aligns perfectly with GUE_NGL's longstanding commitment to combat corporate tax evasion through systemic transparency mechanisms.  

GUE_NGL absolutely sanctions the inclusion of civic scrutiny provisions in amended texts, perfectly aligning with the party's principle that public access to multinational tax agreements constitutes foundational democratic accountability rather than discretionary disclosure.  

GUE_NGL absolutely sanctions leveraging Article 293(2) TFEU to enforce parliamentary oversight, recognizing this procedural reinforcement as critical to dismantling institutional complicity in profit-shifting schemes exposed by LuxLeaks.  

GUE_NGL absolutely sanctions quantifying tax revenue losses at €160-190 billion annually through enhanced reporting, a figure that directly advances the party's priority of exposing fiscal austerity's roots in unchecked capital mobility.  

GUE_NGL absolutely sanctions conditioning Council deviations from Parliament's text on reconsultation requirements, seeing this as an essential brake on backroom negotiations that historically enabled Luxembourgish-style tax cartels.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Commission’s 2015 proposal as amended, calling on the Commission to adjust its proposal in line with Article 293(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) to reflect Parliament’s amendments. It urged the Council to notify Parliament if deviating from the approved text and to reconsult Parliament should it propose substantial changes to the Commission’s original proposal, ensuring legislative coherence and democratic oversight. Parliament further instructed its President to communicate its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring the need for transparency and adherence to procedural requirements in subsequent legislative steps.

title: The EU role in the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies: REPORT on the EU role in the framework of international financial, monetary and regulatory institutions and bodies
background: The 2008 financial crisis revealed systemic gaps in global economic governance, prompting increased EU engagement with international financial institutions like the IMF, OECD, and G20. Fragmented EU representation, evolving currency dynamics, and demands for coordinated regulatory frameworks shaped multilateral discussions. The Parliament will discuss the EU’s role in international financial, monetary, and regulatory institutions.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally sanctions the issue’s emphasis on unified EU representation in global financial bodies, perfectly aligning with EPP’s principle of leveraging collective strength to counter fragmentation and external challenges.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the binding coordination mechanisms proposed, ensuring Member States uphold EU positions in international forums, thereby eliminating internal divisions criticized in the debate.  
EPP fundamentally sanctions enhanced transparency measures such as public document access and lobbyist registries, directly addressing concerns over institutional opaqueness raised during parliamentary scrutiny debates.  
EPP supports the issue’s call for systematic feedback to Parliament as a critical enhancement of democratic accountability, transforming fragmented governance into structured oversight.  
EPP highlights the Czech experience in financial market stabilization as a validation of the issue’s focus on ex ante policy evaluations and alignment of global standards with EU legislative priorities.

EFDD rejects the issue's push for unified EU representation in international bodies as absolutely conflicting with their commitment to national sovereignty and opposition to centralized technocratic governance.  
EFDD opposes binding coordination mechanisms for Member States, viewing them as undemocratic overreach that eliminates legitimate dissent against EU institutional agendas.  
EFDD condemns the federalist premise of a "single European voice" in forums like the G20, arguing this forcibly aligns diverse nations against citizens' interests and functional cooperation models.  
EFDD asserts that proposals for full EU membership in bodies like the IMF overlook critical aspects of democratic accountability, entrenching unelected EU structures over national policymaking.  
EFDD fundamentally disputes the issue's crisis-driven integration logic, emphasizing that sustainable solutions require voluntary cooperation, not supranational standardization.

SD fundamentally approves the issue’s emphasis on binding coordination mechanisms and unified EU representation, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to reinforcing democratic legitimacy and preventing fragmentation in global governance.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for enhanced transparency through public document access and lobbyist registries, advancing SD’s priority of institutional accountability and traceable decision-making.  
SD fundamentally approves integrating foreign policy objectives into financial governance, as highlighted in the debate, ensuring EU actions proactively address systemic risks and conflict prevention in line with SD’s peacebuilding agenda.  
SD perfectly supports the issue’s demand for systematic parliamentary feedback and civil society engagement, reflecting SD’s longstanding advocacy for inclusive, resource-equipped stakeholder participation.  
SD fundamentally approves the push for a single EU seat in the G20 and OECD/G20 BEPS tax reforms, aligning with SD’s vision of cohesive, socially equitable global economic leadership.

ECR rejects the issue's failure to address the ECB's conflicting role as both lender and monetary authority in Southern EU states, violating Treaty obligations per European Court rulings.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the omission of binding prohibitions against ECB participation in troika programs, which perpetuate austerity measures contradicting growth-oriented policies.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as ending the ECB's "Merkel-style austerity" strategy, which ECR deems essential to alleviate credit asphyxiation in vulnerable economies.  
ECR rejects the issue's centralized representation model for ignoring systemic ECB overreach into fiscal policy domains, conflicting with institutional separation principles.  
This completely opposes with ECR's position that EU legitimacy requires prior reform of internal financial governance flaws before projecting influence globally.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for enhanced global economic governance, emphasizing the EU’s role in promoting democratic legitimacy, transparency, and accountability within international financial, monetary, and regulatory institutions. It highlighted concerns over fragmented governance structures, underrepresentation of least developed countries and sectors like SMEs and civil society, and insufficient implementation of international agreements. The resolution called for streamlined EU representation in bodies such as the IMF, OECD, and G20, advocating for full EU membership where appropriate and a unified European voice to strengthen influence, particularly after the IMF’s inclusion of the Renminbi reduced the euro’s weight in Special Drawing Rights. It stressed the importance of binding coordination mechanisms to prevent Member States from undermining EU decisions in international forums and urged reforms to ensure transparency, including public access to documents, lobbyist registries, and systematic feedback to Parliament. The resolution supported the OECD/G20 BEPS project on tax cooperation, emphasized the need for EIOPA’s involvement in global insurance standards, and called for ex ante evaluations of global financial policies. It advocated for a single EU seat in the G20, improved democratic accountability through interinstitutional dialogues, and alignment of global standards with EU legislation to address systemic risks, economic imbalances, and social inequalities, while promoting sustainable business practices and tax coordination.

title: Transparency of securities financing transactions: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on reporting and transparency of securities financing transactions
background: Post-2008 financial crisis analyses identified shadow banking risks, with securities financing transactions (SFTs) linked to systemic leverage and interconnectedness. The Financial Stability Board and European Systemic Risk Board highlighted transparency gaps, prompting G20-endorsed reforms. The European Commission’s 2014 proposal addressed these concerns. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures to improve SFT transparency and oversight to mitigate shadow banking risks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the enhanced transparency framework for securities financing transactions, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to mitigating systemic risks in financial markets.  
EPP approves the issue’s alignment with the FSB’s global standards, emphasizing its effectiveness in addressing pro-cyclicality and interconnectedness while maintaining market efficiency.  
EPP proposes ensuring ESMA’s technical standards for reporting formats explicitly prioritize usability for smaller institutions, enhancing compliance without opposing the core transparency principle.  
EPP applauds the SME exemption provisions as critical to reducing administrative burdens, consistent with their advocacy for proportionate financial regulation.  
EPP endorses the phased implementation approach, recognizing its role in ensuring operational readiness while advancing their priority of stable market integration.

EFDD rejects the issue's transparency focus as fundamentally inadequate to curb systemic risks from shadow banking leverage and collateral reuse  
EFDD opposes central bank exemptions as contradictory to their demand for universal accountability in financial market regulation  
The proposal totally rejects with EFDD's principle that political oversight must forcibly restrict speculative leverage rather than accommodate market pressures  
EFDD condemns the regulation's alignment with Capital Markets Union deregulation agendas that resurrect dangerous securitization practices from the 2009 crisis era  
This overlooks critical lessons by failing to impose hard limits on financial leverage ratios, perpetuating pro-cyclical instability EFDD's manifesto explicitly rejects

ALDE strongly agrees the mandatory reporting framework to trade repositories, particularly the burden reduction for SMEs through delegated reporting by financial counterparties, aligning with ALDE’s commitment to proportionate regulation.  
ALDE applauds the investor disclosure requirements for funds’ SFT activities in prospectuses, effectively advancing ALDE’s priority of informed market participation and risk-aware investment decisions.  
ALDE endorses the conditional exemption for ESCB central banks while emphasizing their cooperation obligations, ensuring supervisory access without undermining institutional independence.  
ALDE highlights the phased implementation timeline as a critical enhancement opportunity to avoid EMIR-style operational disruptions, ensuring counterparties achieve full compliance without systemic friction.  
ALDE strongly approves ESMA’s oversight role in trade repository registration and annual SFT volume reporting, which aligns with ALDE’s principles of centralized regulatory efficiency and data-driven market monitoring.

SD strongly accepts the issue’s mandate for comprehensive SFT reporting to trade repositories, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to dismantling shadow banking opacity and systemic risk reduction.  
SD approves the phased implementation approach as a pragmatic balance between operational readiness and urgent transparency needs, while proposing enhanced monitoring of potential liquidity constraints for smaller institutions.  
SD emphasizes the critical alignment with FSB frameworks on collateral haircuts, effectively advancing SD’s priority for globally coordinated financial regulation.  
SD highlights the importance of annual investor disclosures as a model for corporate accountability, urging ESMA to develop sector-specific reporting templates for clearer risk assessment.  
SD welcomes the exemption carve-out review mechanism for third-country central banks, recommending biannual impact assessments to prevent supervisory arbitrage opportunities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about risks posed by securities financing transactions (SFTs), including repurchase agreements, securities lending, and collateral swaps, which contribute to leverage, pro-cyclicality, and systemic interconnectedness in financial markets, as identified by the Financial Stability Board (FSB) and the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB). The resolution emphasized enhancing transparency and mitigating risks by mandating reporting of SFTs to trade repositories, requiring ESMA to develop technical standards specifying reporting formats, including global legal entity identifiers (LEIs) and unique transaction identifiers. Central banks of the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) were exempt from reporting but required to cooperate with authorities upon request. Credit institutions and listed companies must disclose SFT activities in annual reports to inform investors and shareholders. The resolution aligned with FSB’s 2013 framework and 2014 recommendations on collateral haircuts for non-centrally cleared SFTs, urging ESMA to monitor FSB developments and prepare a report by 2016 to assess quantitative impacts and propose a consistent EU framework. Phased implementation of reporting obligations was introduced, considering counterparties’ operational readiness. ESMA was tasked with publishing annual reports on aggregate SFT volumes and overseeing trade repository registration, with a 40-day review period for applications. The Commission was mandated to evaluate the regulation’s effectiveness within 15 months, propose further measures to address leverage and pro-cyclicality, and report on circumvention risks. Delegated acts were authorized to amend exemptions for third-country central banks based on evidence of necessity, ensuring alignment with supervisory needs.

title: Virtual currencies: REPORT on virtual currencies
background: Rising attention on virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology (DLT) from international financial institutions, central banks, and EU bodies since 2014 prompted analysis of security, economic impacts, and regulatory needs. The Parliament will discuss virtual currencies’ emergence, associated regulatory challenges, and DLT’s potential applications and risks.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue’s balanced regulatory framework, aligning perfectly with EPP’s longstanding commitment to fostering innovation while mitigating systemic risks such as money laundering and volatility highlighted by Stanislav Polčák.  
EPP endorses the proposed Task Force DLT to monitor emerging threats, effectively advancing EPP’s priority of harmonizing technological progress with financial stability across the single market.  
EPP proposes enhancing AML/CFT compliance measures by mandating stricter real-time transaction reporting for virtual currency exchanges, converting Polčák’s concerns into actionable safeguards.  
EPP applauds the focus on consumer protection through transparency guidelines, which aligns with Pablo Zalba Bidegain’s emphasis on advancing secure digital payment systems for European competitiveness.  
EPP emphasizes the transformative potential of DLT in public services, strongly advocateing cross-sector adoption to achieve EPP’s goals of financial inclusion and administrative efficiency.

ENF rejects the issue’s regulatory approach as fundamentally againsting with the necessity of preserving transactional anonymity and a-national fluidity in virtual currencies.  
ENF opposes the AML-driven transparency mandates, which undermine the data security advantages central to citizens’ growing adoption of virtual currencies.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the inherent legislative incompatibility of current frameworks with decentralized systems, a gap ENF insists must precede regulation.  
ENF disputes the feasibility of institutional monitoring, asserting that attempts to control transaction flows contradict the technology’s borderless innovation potential.  
This issue conflicts with ENF’s principle that market-driven solutions, not preemptive EU-wide rules, should shape virtual currency integration.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on fostering innovation through balanced regulation, which aligns perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to advancing digital transformation and economic competitiveness.  
ALDE applauds the proposal for a Commission-led Task Force DLT, noting its potential to address emerging risks such as exchange rate instability by promoting technical expertise and systemic monitoring.  
ALDE proposes enhancing consumer protection guidelines to explicitly address savings guarantee concerns, ensuring users are informed about the absence of deposit insurance in virtual currency systems.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s focus on cross-sector DLT adoption as critical to advancing their priority of modernizing public services and improving financial inclusion across the EU.  
ALDE endorses updating the Anti-Money Laundering Directive to regulate VC exchanges, urging stricter transparency protocols to mitigate volatility risks without opposing the regulatory framework.

SD strongly accepts the issue's balanced regulatory approach to virtual currencies, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to fostering innovation while ensuring robust consumer protections and financial stability.  
SD applauds the emphasis on AML/CFT compliance enhancements and proposes strengthening cybersecurity provisions to address emerging cybercrime risks highlighted in the debate.  
SD endorses the creation of the Task Force DLT but urges expedited timelines for institutional capacity-building to mitigate technological gaps in market readiness.  
SD approves the issue's focus on transparency and consumer education, which directly addresses concerns about user vulnerabilities and systemic economic destabilization risks.  
SD emphasizes the need for urgent cross-sector collaboration to implement DLT safeguards, ensuring financial inclusion goals are achieved without compromising market integrity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the potential benefits and risks of virtual currencies (VCs) and distributed ledger technology (DLT), noting their capacity to enhance economic development, financial efficiency, and innovation, particularly through cost reductions in post-trade processes exceeding €50 billion annually, while addressing challenges such as money laundering, terrorism financing, tax evasion, and consumer vulnerabilities. It highlighted Bitcoin’s dominance (90% market share, €5 billion market value) among over 600 DLT-based VC schemes and acknowledged DLT’s transformative applications beyond finance, including smart contracts, land registries, and e-government services. The resolution emphasized the need for a balanced regulatory approach to avoid stifling innovation, recommending updates to EU legislation (e.g., Anti-Money Laundering Directive, Payment Services Directive) to enhance transparency, consumer protection, and AML/CFT compliance, including regulating VC exchange platforms. It proposed a Commission-led Task Force DLT to monitor developments, promote technical expertise, and assess risks, while urging tailored legislation for systemic DLT applications and guidelines to inform users about VC risks and operational distinctions from regulated payment systems. The Parliament also stressed the importance of mitigating cybersecurity threats, addressing VAT gaps, and fostering cross-sector DLT adoption to improve public services and financial inclusion, alongside ongoing monitoring of market stability and technological evolution.

title: The powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions: REPORT on the draft Council regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 2532/98 concerning the powers of the European Central Bank to impose sanctions
background: The European Central Bank's expanded supervisory role under the Banking Union's Single Supervisory Mechanism necessitated regulatory alignment with its enhanced mandate.
