The Parliament will discuss amendments to ECB powers regarding sanctioning authority and statistical data collection procedures for financial institutions.

stances.stance:
EFDD entirely againsts the issue as it entrenches ECB authority over national economies, contradicting their core principle of sovereign monetary control  
EFDD rejects the premise of ECB sanctioning powers, viewing this as incremental federalism that ignores the eurozone's structural unsustainability  
The proposal fails to address EFDD's primary demand to dismantle the euro and restore national currencies as adjustment mechanisms  
EFDD condemns the issue's alignment with permanent transfer mechanisms between member states, violating subsidiarity principles  
This framework completely rejects with EFDD's belief in democratic accountability through national governments rather than supranational banking institutions

GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the issue's procedural rigor in safeguarding parliamentary oversight, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle of institutional accountability in EU governance.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the requirement for renewed Council consultation on substantial amendments, viewing this as critical to preventing opaque deviations from agreed financial oversight frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s enforcement of Treaty-based transparency mechanisms, recognizing this as a model for disciplined legislative focus that avoids tangential debates.

ALDE entirely promotes the ECB's expanded sanctioning authority as perfectly aligning with their commitment to robust financial oversight and crisis prevention.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with directing bank fines to the issue fund under the "polluter pays" principle, a cornerstone of their regulatory philosophy.  
ALDE entirely promotes mandatory transparency in publishing finalized sanctions, advancing their priority of market stability through accountable enforcement.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with enhanced information-sharing requirements for banks, recognizing this as critical to effective supervisory cooperation.  
ALDE emphasizes strict adherence to procedural timelines for investigations, reflecting their institutional commitment to decisive yet methodical oversight.

SD opposes fundamentally the issue's failure to integrate sanctions revenue into the banking issue fund, directly contradicting SD's demand for a sustainable, EU-level financial safety net.  
SD rejects the omission of explicit ECB supervisory thresholds (€30B assets or 20% GDP), which SD deems essential to prevent cross-border systemic risks in the interconnected banking landscape.  
SD highlights the issue's inconsistency with SD's vision of a fortified banking union, as it neglects to expand the ECB’s mandate to cover liquidity safeguards for high-risk banks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the European Central Bank’s draft recommendation as amended, emphasizing the need for the Council to notify Parliament if it intends to deviate from the approved text or propose substantial amendments, which would require renewed consultation. It underscored adherence to procedural obligations under relevant EU treaties and the Statute of the European System of Central Banks, while instructing its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, the ECB, and the Commission to ensure alignment and transparency in the legislative process.

title: Competition policy – annual report 2021: REPORT on competition policy – annual report 2021 | A9-0064/2022 | European Parliament
background: The EU faced post-pandemic economic recovery challenges, accelerated green/digital transitions under the European Green Deal, rising energy prices exacerbated by geopolitical tensions, and evolving digital market dynamics requiring updated competition frameworks. The Parliament will discuss 2021 competition policy adaptations to address economic resilience, sustainability, and fair market practices in evolving global conditions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the issue's prioritization of SME competitiveness and digital innovation, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to fostering dynamic, business-friendly markets across rural and urban regions.  
EPP approves the phased normalization of COVID-19 State aid frameworks while advocating for expanded eligibility criteria to include energy-intensive SMEs disproportionately affected by price volatility.  
EPP endorses the DMA and DSA as critical tools to curb monopolistic digital practices, proposing enhanced enforcement mechanisms to impose structural remedies beyond fines for systemic rule-breakers.  
EPP welcomes the revised State aid guidelines for green transitions but urges flexibility to accommodate sector-specific timelines for coal phase-outs in less-developed regions.  
EPP emphasizes vigilance against foreign subsidy distortions, aligning with the issue’s call for robust Foreign Subsidies Regulation implementation to protect strategic EU industries.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on aligning State aid with climate-neutral technologies under the European Green Deal, which directly advances their commitment to accelerating the energy transition.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the phase-out of temporary COVID-19 aid frameworks but proposes enhancing transparency mechanisms to prevent multinational beneficiaries from channeling funds to tax havens, ensuring equitable treatment for SMEs.  

GREEN_EFA strongly endorses the Digital Markets Act’s potential to dismantle monopolistic practices, urging Parliament to guarantee robust enforcement resources and prioritize data fairness in merger evaluations.  

GREEN_EFA emphasizes the imperative to explicitly exclude fossil fuel subsidies from revised State aid guidelines, aligning competition policy with the climate emergency’s urgency rather than prolonging energy market vulnerabilities.  

GREEN_EFA welcomes the issue’s caution against airline industry consolidation fueled by pandemic-era aid, calling for stricter safeguards to prevent monopolistic structures that undermine sustainable transport alternatives.

ID rejects fundamentally the issue’s endorsement of State aid for green transitions, as it creates artificial market divisions and undermines industrial competitiveness, contradicting ID’s principle of minimizing state intervention in the economy.  
ID opposes the issue’s support for coal phase-outs, which overlooks critical aspects of energy security and affordability, instead advocating for a revival of coal and nuclear energy to protect jobs and stabilize prices.  
ID condemns the issue’s alignment with the European Green Deal, arguing it disregards the EU’s negligible global climate impact while dismantling key industries, consistent with ID’s stance against economically destructive environmental policies.  
ID challenges the issue’s reliance on digital market regulations like the DMA and DSA, viewing them as overreach that stifles innovation, in direct conflict with ID’s advocacy for deregulation and market freedom.  
ID rejects the issue’s call for global cooperation on competition policy, asserting it weakens EU sovereignty and fails to address the risks of foreign subsidy distortions adequately, reflecting ID’s prioritization of national economic autonomy.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to address energy market oligopolies enabled by EU privatization mandates, which directly contradict public ownership principles vital for equitable transitions.  
GUE_NGL opposes the phased withdrawal of State aid frameworks as this entrenches corporate control over energy systems, undermining Member States’ capacity to enact green industrial policies.  
The issue entirely disapproves with GUE_NGL’s demand for price caps and windfall taxes on energy cartels profiteering from geopolitical crises, ignoring Article 7’s lax merger controls on digital-energy monopolies.  
GUE_NGL condemns the hypocrisy of penalizing states pursuing public energy transition projects while permitting pandemic-era airline consolidation aided by State subsidies.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as re-nationalizing energy infrastructure to break oligopolistic pricing, a core GUE_NGL remedy for the 400% gas cost surge noted in the issue.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of EU competition policy in fostering innovation, job creation, and sustainable growth while addressing challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic, the digital and green transitions, and global market dynamics. It emphasized the need to phase out temporary COVID-19 State aid frameworks progressively to avoid market fragmentation, particularly noting that gas prices surged by 400% in autumn 2021 compared to spring 2021, underscoring energy market vulnerabilities. The resolution highlighted SMEs, representing 99.8% of EU businesses, as vital to economic recovery but facing financing challenges, and urged targeted support for rural and less-developed regions. It welcomed the Digital Markets Act (DMA) and Digital Services Act (DSA) to curb monopolistic practices in digital markets, stressing the need for adequate enforcement resources and synergies with antitrust tools. Concerns over foreign subsidies distorting the single market led to calls for robust implementation of the Foreign Subsidies Regulation and enhanced global cooperation, including through the EU-US Trade and Technology Council. The Parliament supported revised State aid guidelines aligned with the European Green Deal, including aid for coal phase-outs and climate-neutral technologies, while cautioning against airline industry consolidation fueled by pandemic-era State aid. It urged modernization of merger control rules to address data concentration, zero-price markets, and "killer acquisitions," emphasizing personal data’s role in digital mergers. Antitrust reforms were advocated to tackle vertical agreements, geo-blocking, and territorial supply constraints, alongside stronger enforcement against anti-competitive practices in agriculture, IoT, and digital advertising. The resolution also stressed the independence of national competition authorities, transparency in State aid evaluations, and vigilance against tax avoidance-linked distortions, while calling for flexibility to support sectors impacted by Russia’s aggression against Ukraine.

title: EU coordinated action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on EU coordinated action to combat the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences | RC-B9-0143/2020 | European Parliament
background: None

stances.stance:
SD completely upholds the creation of recovery bonds to mutualize debt across member states, perfectly aligning with the issue's call for ambitious financial solidarity mechanisms.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands to center the European Green Deal in reconstruction efforts, viewing this as essential for building sustainable post-pandemic economies.  
SD fully supports establishing EU-wide protections for women and vulnerable groups during lockdowns, enhancing the issue's human rights focus through concrete anti-violence measures.  
SD completely upholds proposals for a Roosevelt-style investment program funded by progressive EU-wide corporate taxes and financial transaction levies.  
SD perfectly aligns with calls to strengthen public healthcare systems through coordinated EU procurement of medical equipment and permanent crisis response structures.

RENEW strongly upholds the issue’s condemnation of Turkey’s withdrawal from the Istanbul Convention, aligning perfectly with RENEW's longstanding commitment to gender equality and the eradication of violence against women.  
RENEW approves the linkage of EU funding to democratic reforms, effectively advancing RENEW's priority of conditioning financial support on tangible progress in judicial independence and civil liberties.  
RENEW endorses the suspension of accession negotiations, consistent with their principle that EU integration requires full adherence to rule of law, while advocating to formalize migration and counterterrorism cooperation through separate structured dialogues.  
RENEW proposes amending Clause 12 to specify quarterly benchmarks for judicial transparency reforms, ensuring the €4.7 billion migration deal is adjusted proportionally to verifiable improvements.  
RENEW applauds the push for targeted sanctions against human rights violators, mirroring RENEW's 2023 manifesto emphasis on enforcing accountability through EU mechanisms.

GREEN_EFA rejects fundamentally the issue's failure to address pandemic-driven inequalities and democratic backsliding within EU states, inconsistent with their core social justice principles.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the prioritization of external border disputes over urgent climate-economic reconstruction needs outlined in their pandemic recovery manifesto.  
This proposal conflicts irreconcilably with GREEN_EFA's demand for EU-wide debt mutualization and green reinvestment, absent from the issue's financial clauses.  
The issue overlooks critical migrant protections and healthcare access crises exacerbated by COVID-19, central to Verts/ALE's debate priorities.

ID rejects the issue's call for continued EU funding to Turkey as fundamentally inconsistent with ID's demand to prioritize European citizens' needs over foreign aid.  
ID opposes maintaining migration cooperation with Turkey, citing the debate's emphasis on uncontrolled migration flows exacerbating health crises.  
The proposal's focus on democratic reforms in Turkey conflicts with ID's primary concern over EU's own democratic deficit and bureaucratic overreach highlighted in the debate.  
ID fundamentally objects to expanding EU's role in pandemic response coordination, aligning with arguments that national governments must retain full sovereignty over health policies.  
The issue's sanctions proposal overlooks ID's documented criticism of EU financial waste, failing to address systemic corruption within EU institutions first.

resolution: The European Parliament raised significant concerns over the deteriorating rule of law, human rights, and media freedom in Turkey, citing the arbitrary detention of journalists, activists, and opposition figures, with over 300 journalists prosecuted since 2019. It condemned Turkey’s withdrawal from the Istanbul Convention on combating violence against women and urged the government to reverse policies undermining judicial independence and civil liberties. The resolution called for a reassessment of EU funding to Turkey, particularly the €4.7 billion allocated under the 2016 migration deal, stressing that financial support must align with democratic reforms and human rights compliance. It reiterated opposition to Turkey’s unilateral actions in the Eastern Mediterranean, including drilling activities near Cyprus, and urged dialogue to resolve territorial disputes. Parliament also demanded the EU suspend accession negotiations with Turkey, citing a lack of progress on key reforms, while advocating for continued engagement on migration, counterterrorism, and trade. Additionally, it urged the Commission to propose targeted sanctions against individuals responsible for human rights violations and corruption. The resolution emphasized the need for a balanced, conditional partnership with Turkey, prioritizing democratic values and regional stability.

title: Administrative cooperation in the field of taxation: REPORT on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation | A9-0015/2021 | European Parliament
background: The European Union's existing framework for cross-border tax administrative cooperation, established under Directive 2011/16/EU, faced challenges in addressing evolving digital economy activities and ensuring comprehensive reporting requirements. The Parliament will discuss proposed amendments to strengthen multilateral tax transparency and adapt information-sharing mechanisms to contemporary economic practices.

stances.stance:
EPP completely agrees the issue’s expansion of automatic information exchange between Member States, perfectly aligning with EPP’s longstanding commitment to combat tax evasion through enhanced cross-border transparency.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the suspension of information exchanges in cases of rule of law breaches linked to EU budget conditionality, reinforcing fiscal integrity as a cornerstone of EPP’s governance priorities.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for stable legislative frameworks to avoid administrative disruption, proposing a comprehensive revision of Directive 2011/16/EU to consolidate successive amendments into a coherent structure.  
EPP strongly advocates the updated definitions and procedural rules, which effectively advance EPP’s goal of reducing bureaucratic burdens while maintaining robust taxpayer rights and data protection standards.  
EPP highlights the urgency of allocating sufficient resources to national tax administrations to operationalize these measures, ensuring the issue’s ambitions translate into practical enforcement gains.

SD entirely accepts the expanded automatic exchange of platform data as critical to dismantling systemic tax avoidance by digital giants like Airbnb and Uber, perfectly aligning with SD’s decade-long advocacy for closing cross-border loopholes.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s integration of rule-of-law conditionality into tax cooperation, recognizing this as a necessary safeguard against budgetary fraud that SD prioritized in its 2021 Anti-Corruption Report.  
SD unequivocally supports binding member states to disclose cross-border rulings involving platforms, a mechanism that directly advances SD’s manifesto pledge to "tax value where it is created" in the digital economy.  
 While commending the issue’s transparency mandates, SD emphasizes that persistent Council delays in implementing DAC frameworks require accelerated enforcement timelines to match public urgency.  
SD champions the issue’s updated procedural rules as a transformative step toward pan-European tax justice, mirroring SD-led initiatives like the 2023 Public Country-by-Country Reporting Directive.

ID rejects the issue's expansion of automatic information exchange as a fundamental violation of citizens' privacy rights and EU data protection standards.  
ID opposes the increased bureaucratic reporting requirements for digital platforms, citing the European Court of Auditors' evidence of excessive costs and negligible operational effectiveness.  
ID fully challenges with the issue's tax transparency framework, arguing it accelerates the EU's competitiveness decline through higher taxation and regulatory burdens on businesses.  
ID condemns the proposal's alignment with broader agendas to finance "Euro, climate rescue, and migration" through pervasive fiscal surveillance, contradicting principles of national sovereignty.  
ID challenges the issue's neglect of Rechtsstaatlichkeit, advocating instead for targeted anti-tax evasion measures that respect legal certainty and proportionality.

GUE_NGL entirely promotes the issue's suspension of information exchanges for rule of law breaches, recognizing this as a vital safeguard against member states enabling intra-EU tax havens.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the expanded automatic information exchange provisions, viewing them as essential to combat multinational tax avoidance and reclaim public revenues for social services.  
GUE_NGL strongly accepts the reinforced transparency requirements for cross-border rulings, seeing this as a critical step toward ending the destructive "race to the bottom" in corporate taxation.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes that the issue effectively advances their decades-long campaign against capital flight and fiscal predation by harmonizing enforcement with EU budget conditionality mechanisms.  
GUE_NGL applauds the mandatory alignment with EU treaties as a necessary framework to override obstructionist national agendas undermining collective fiscal justice.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the Commission’s amended proposal (COM(2020)0314) to strengthen administrative cooperation in taxation, amending Directive 2011/16/EU to enhance tax transparency, expand automatic exchange of information between member states, and reinforce enforcement mechanisms. Key amendments introduced provisions to suspend information exchanges in cases of rule of law breaches linked to EU budget conditionality, expanded reporting requirements for cross-border tax rulings and financial transactions, and updated definitions and procedural rules to improve compliance. The resolution emphasized ensuring alignment with EU legal frameworks, including references to relevant treaties and regulations, and mandated the Commission to revise its proposal accordingly. It urged the Council to consult Parliament again if intending substantial changes and directed the transmission of the Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure procedural coherence and legislative transparency.

title: European Semester for economic policy coordination: annual sustainable growth survey 2022: REPORT on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: annual sustainable growth survey 2022 | A9-0034/2022 | European Parliament
background: The European Union faced post-pandemic economic recovery challenges, including uneven growth, rising public debt, energy price volatility, and supply chain disruptions amid ongoing implementation of the Recovery and Resilience Facility. The Parliament will discuss the European Semester’s coordination of fiscal policies, structural reforms, and investment priorities to address sustainability, competitiveness, and macroeconomic stability.

stances.stance:
SD fundamentally approves the issue's integration of social objectives with digital and environmental priorities, perfectly aligning with S&D's commitment to a just recovery that combats inequality through wealth redistribution and robust welfare systems.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's call to prolong the Stability and Growth Pact's escape clause, recognizing its critical role in enabling public investments for energy independence and social protection amid geopolitical crises.  
SD fundamentally approves the emphasis on democratic accountability and social partner involvement in the European Semester, mirroring S&D's demand for transparent, inclusive policymaking that elevates workers' rights and SME support.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's focus on fair fiscal policies, endorsing its push to combat tax evasion and ensure multinationals contribute equitably to sustain social stability during economic transitions.  
SD fundamentally approves leveraging the Recovery and Resilience Facility to accelerate sustainable transitions, aligning with S&D's vision of EU-wide solidarity in achieving climate goals while safeguarding vulnerable populations from energy price shocks.

GREEN_EFA absolutely accepts the issue’s emphasis on extending the Stability and Growth Pact’s escape clause, perfectly aligning with their demand for sustained fiscal flexibility to address energy crises and asymmetric recovery.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for EU intervention in energy markets, particularly decoupling gas prices from electricity pricing mechanisms to mitigate inflationary pressures on households.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely accepts accelerating green transition investments through a dedicated EU fund, mirroring their manifesto priority to frontload climate action amid geopolitical energy shocks.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s focus on territorial cohesion, strongly upholding strict adherence to RRF plans to prevent regional disparities like those exacerbating Italy’s North-South divide.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely accepts integrating climate urgency into fiscal governance reforms, recognizing this as critical to achieving the issue’s debt sustainability goals through green investment incentives.

ID rejects the issue's emphasis on green taxation and punitive ecological measures, which fully disapprove with ID's position that economic policies must prioritize citizens' immediate survival needs over climate dogmas.  
ID opposes the Stability and Growth Pact reactivation framework as perpetuating austerity mechanisms that have caused 20 years of subpar Eurozone growth compared to OECD peers, directly contradicting issue Clause 12 on debt sustainability.  
ID denounces the Next Generation EU's "rigidly schematized" recovery plans for creating artificial dependencies on imported technologies while exacerbating economic asymmetries through flawed growth multipliers, as evidenced in Italy's debt trap.  
ID fully disapproves the issue's ecosocialist transformation agenda, which seeks to invest trillions in "socio-ecological transition" while ignoring how energy price inflation from green policies destroys European industries and household budgets.  
ID condemns the ECB's continued debt monetization as inflationary theft that violates Maastricht principles, with Eurozone states now spending beyond their productive capacity as warned in issue Clause 5 about public debt risks.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's failure to commit to permanent abolition of Stability and Growth Pact austerity rules, which directly contradict their anti-austerity principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the planned 2023 reactivation of fiscal constraints, citing Manon Aubry's warnings about energy poverty and hospital cuts under such regimes.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's vagueness on debt sustainability reforms as enabling continued ordoliberal governance, echoing José Gusmão's critique of contradictory paragraphs.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal's incompatibility with crisis response needs, aligning with Chris MacManus' demand to suspend rules until 2024 amid wartime economic shocks.  
GUE_NGL denounces the omission of binding social equity targets, reflecting Eugenia Rodríguez Palop's call to prioritize working-class conditions over deficit obsessions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the EU’s economic recovery post-COVID-19, noting projected GDP growth of 4.3% in 2022 for the euro area and EU-27, slowing to 2.4% and 2.5% respectively in 2023, alongside significant disparities in recovery rates among Member States (ranging from 2.7% to 14.6% in 2021). It highlighted risks from new pandemic variants, energy prices, inflation, supply disruptions, and labor shortages, which threaten sustainable and digital transitions. Unemployment rates were noted to have fallen to 7.9% in the euro area and 7.1% in the EU-27 in 2021, with further declines expected. The resolution emphasized the surge in public debt (100% of GDP in the euro area, 92.1% in the EU-27) and stressed the need for coordinated fiscal policies, structural reforms, and investments to address imbalances, enhance productivity, and ensure debt sustainability. It underscored the critical role of the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) in financing green and digital transitions, urging Member States to align national plans with RRF objectives, tackle tax fraud and evasion, and ensure compliance with the Rule of Law Conditionality Regulation. The Parliament called for addressing macroeconomic imbalances in 12 Member States, prioritizing socially balanced reforms, and enhancing women’s economic participation. It advocated for a revised EU fiscal governance framework ahead of deactivating the Stability and Growth Pact’s general escape clause in 2023, while maintaining supportive fiscal stances tailored to national debt levels. The resolution stressed democratic accountability, urging stronger parliamentary involvement in the European Semester process and coordination with social partners to ensure transparency and inclusive policymaking.

title: European Semester: Annual Sustainable Growth Strategy 2021: REPORT on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Sustainable Growth Strategy 2021 | A9-0036/2021 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic triggered a severe EU-wide economic contraction, rising public debt, and asymmetric socio-economic impacts, prompting activation of the Stability and Growth Pact’s general escape clause and establishment of the Recovery and Resilience Facility. The Parliament will discuss aligning the European Semester with post-pandemic recovery priorities, structural reforms, and sustainable investment coordination.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly approves the issue's emphasis on the Recovery and Resilience Facility, perfectly aligning with their commitment to structural reforms and SME support through coordinated national investment plans.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for growth-enhancing structural reforms, emphasizing fiscal responsibility and efficient use of NextGenerationEU funds to avoid unsustainable debt.  
EPP firmly approves enhanced democratic accountability in the European Semester process, advocating for strengthened parliamentary oversight to ensure transparent implementation of recovery measures.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's focus on social fairness, supporting targeted investments in healthcare, education, and disability inclusion to address pandemic-exacerbated inequalities.  
EPP firmly approves the urgency of combating tax evasion and corruption, emphasizing that proper fund allocation is essential for achieving green transition goals and maintaining public trust.

SD strongly upholds the revision of the Stability and Growth Pact to reflect post-pandemic debt realities, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to sustainable fiscal flexibility that prioritizes green and digital investments over austerity measures.  
SD approves the integration of social resilience and healthcare strengthening into the European Semester process, effectively advancing SD’s priority of upward convergence and robust social safety nets as pillars of crisis recovery.  
SD endorses the imperative to embed gender equality metrics within recovery strategies, ensuring the Annual Sustainable Growth Strategy addresses systemic employment and wage gaps exacerbated by the pandemic.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of maintaining the general escape clause until pre-crisis economic levels are restored, aligning with SD’s longstanding opposition to premature fiscal consolidation that risks social cohesion.  
SD proposes enhancing the Semester’s regional adaptability to address peripheral and insular disparities, ensuring reforms account for diverse economic contexts while upholding debt sustainability goals.

ECR firmly againsts the issue’s structural reforms and fiscal policy coordination as violating subsidiarity, citing excessive EU-level indicators that encroach on member states’ competence over social and employment policies.  
ECR rejects the reliance on the Stability and Growth Pact’s general escape clause, arguing it rewards fiscal irresponsibility and undermines incentives for thrifty states that maintained disciplined reforms.  
ECR opposes subordinating economic recovery to environmental priorities, condemning the issue’s “ecocentrism” as ideologically driven and incompatible with urgent post-pandemic competitiveness needs.  
ECR criticizes the issue’s inadequate focus on strengthening national healthcare systems, noting the omission of concrete investment mechanisms for crisis preparedness in recovery plans.  
ECR condemns redistribution of fiscal reserves via EU instruments as penalizing fiscally conservative states, warning it replicates socialist-style resource depletion contrary to sustainable growth.

GUE_NGL fundamentally rejects the issue's promotion of structural reforms that perpetuate austerity-driven policies responsible for dismantling public healthcare systems and social safety nets across Europe.  
GUE_NGL opposes the continued enforcement of Stability and Growth Pact frameworks, condemning their role in accelerating regional disparities and imposing destructive wage suppression disguised as "competitiveness" measures.  
GUE_NGL challenges the issue's growth obsession, noting its 34 mentions of economic expansion versus zero references to healthcare, exposing a lethal disregard for pandemic lessons about public service underfunding.  
GUE_NGL denounces the European Semester's historical complicity in tax haven proliferation while demanding criminalization of profit-driven health privatizations enabled by fiscal consolidation rules.  
GUE_NGL demands abolition of the RRF's reform conditionality that forces privatization of pensions/social security systems under the guise of "digital transition" investments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the severe economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, noting a 6.3% GDP contraction in the EU (6.8% in the euro area) in 2020 and projecting a 2021 recovery of 3.7% (3.8% in the euro area), with public debt rising to 93.9% of GDP in the EU (101.7% in the euro area) in 2020. It emphasized the critical role of the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) in aligning national reforms and investments with EU priorities, including the green and digital transitions, social fairness, and the UN Sustainable Development Goals, while urging swift implementation and transparency. The resolution highlighted the need for growth-enhancing structural reforms, sustainable fiscal policies, and investments in SMEs, digital infrastructure, and climate resilience, stressing the importance of maintaining the activated general escape clause of the Stability and Growth Pact to allow fiscal flexibility during the crisis. It called for improved democratic accountability in the European Semester process, stronger parliamentary oversight, and coordination with social partners, while advocating for a future review of fiscal rules to balance flexibility with long-term debt sustainability. The Parliament also underscored the urgency of addressing macroeconomic imbalances, tax evasion, and money laundering, and urged prioritizing cross-border projects, climate indicators aligned with the Paris Agreement, and measures to mitigate regional disparities exacerbated by the pandemic.

title: European Withholding Tax framework: REPORT on a European Withholding Tax framework | A9-0011/2022 | European Parliament
background: Persistent cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive profit shifting via royalties and dividends, and fragmented national withholding tax systems, alongside cum-ex/cum-cum scandals causing significant revenue losses, prompted EU institutional responses. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing withholding tax procedures to combat fraud, prevent double taxation, and facilitate cross-border investment within the Single Market.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally endorses the harmonized withholding tax framework as perfectly aligning with their vision for a competitive Capital Markets Union free of bureaucratic barriers to cross-border investment.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's digital transformation agenda, advocating blockchain solutions to streamline refund processes while preventing fraud through enhanced transparency.  
EPP strongly approves the swift adoption of OECD Pillar II reforms, recognizing their critical role in establishing fair tax competition and generating €63.9 billion annually for EU Member States.  
EPP applauds the issue's focus on combating cum-ex schemes via unique dividend identifiers and cross-border cooperation, advancing their decade-long anti-tax evasion priorities.  
EPP emphasizes the framework's balance between preventing double taxation and respecting national fiscal sovereignty, ensuring market integration without imposing uniform tax rates.

SD firmly endorses the harmonized withholding tax framework as a critical step to eradicate cross-border dividend arbitrage schemes, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to closing €140 billion cum-ex/cum-cum loopholes through unified EU tax borders.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's demand for blockchain-enabled refund systems, emphasizing this digital enforcement mechanism directly advances SD's anti-fraud priorities and prevents €8.4 billion annual administrative leakage.  
SD firmly endorses binding OECD Pillar II implementation, recognizing the 15% global minimum tax as fully congruent with SD's decade-long campaign against profit-shifting to low-tax jurisdictions.  
SD unequivocally supports the call for real-time tax authority cooperation through DAC6 enhancements, mirroring SD's manifesto pledge to dismantle banking complicity in cum-ex schemes via mandatory dividend identifiers.  
SD perfectly aligns with the urgency for Capital Markets Union integration, viewing standardized withholding relief as essential to SD's vision of market integrity free from treaty shopping and royalty rerouting.

GREEN_EFA totally accepts the issue's demand for EU-wide minimum withholding tax rates on interest, royalties, and dividends, perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to dismantle profit-shifting structures.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to extend withholding tax safeguards to outbound payments beyond the EU, a critical measure to prevent global tax base erosion as outlined in their 2023 fiscal justice agenda.  
GREEN_EFA totally accepts holding the European Banking Authority and ESMA accountable for cum-ex oversight failures, reflecting their decade-long advocacy for rigorous enforcement against dividend arbitrage fraud.  
GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s urgency in adopting blockchain-based refund systems, which directly advances their digital transparency goals while recovering €8.4 billion annually in administrative efficiencies.  
GREEN_EFA totally accepts binding the Capital Markets Union to anti-avoidance measures, mirroring their demands to embed OECD Pillar II standards into all EU financial integration policies.

ECR strongly approves the harmonized withholding tax framework, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to eliminating cross-border tax abuse and recovering €140 billion lost to Cum-EX schemes.  
ECR applauds the issue’s focus on digital refund mechanisms like blockchain, effectively advancing ECR's priority of cutting bureaucratic costs while securing €20 billion annually for Member States.  
ECR proposes amending Article 4 to mandate a pan-EU legal definition of "real beneficiary," addressing divergent national interpretations that currently enable profit rerouting and treaty shopping.  
ECR underscores the critical need for immediate DAC6 enforcement enhancements to strengthen cross-border tax authority cooperation, as delayed action has historically fueled systemic vulnerabilities.  
ECR commends the issue’s alignment with OECD Pillar II reforms, which directly reinforce ECR’s manifesto goals of ensuring fair tax competition and market integrity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent tax avoidance and evasion within the EU, citing annual revenue losses ranging from €36-37 billion to €160-190 billion due to corporate tax avoidance, with €140 billion lost between 2000-2020 from cum-ex/cum-cum schemes. It highlighted the need to address profit-shifting channels like royalty, interest, and dividend payments, exacerbated by fragmented withholding tax systems (rates varying 0-35%) and complex refund procedures costing €8.4 billion in 2016. The resolution welcomed the OECD/G20 two-pillar tax reform, including a 15% global minimum corporate tax rate (Pillar II), projected to generate €63.9 billion annually for EU Member States, and urged swift adoption of related EU legislation. It called for a harmonized EU-wide withholding tax framework to prevent double taxation, treaty shopping, and profit rerouting, emphasizing digital solutions (e.g., blockchain) for streamlined refund processes and fraud prevention. The Parliament stressed the urgency of tackling cum-ex schemes through measures like unique dividend identifiers, enhanced cross-border tax authority cooperation, and stricter enforcement of anti-abuse rules under directives like DAC6. It urged the Commission to propose a standardized withholding tax relief system by 2022, align tax treaties with OECD standards, and integrate anti-tax avoidance measures into the Capital Markets Union. Additionally, the resolution emphasized reforms to the Parent-Subsidiary and Interest-Royalties Directives, including minimum effective tax rates, and stronger defensive measures against non-cooperative tax jurisdictions to safeguard the EU’s tax base and market integrity.

title: Fair and simple taxation supporting the recovery strategy: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on fair and simple taxation supporting the recovery strategy (EP follow-up to the July Commission’s Action Plan and its 25 initiatives in the area of VAT, business and individual taxation) | A9-0024/2022 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic strained EU fiscal stability through reduced tax revenues, increased debt, and heightened spending, exacerbating pre-existing challenges like VAT fraud, corporate tax avoidance, and administrative burdens on SMEs. The Parliament will discuss reforms to simplify taxation, enhance cross-border cooperation, and align EU tax policy with OECD/G20 agreements to support economic recovery.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the harmonization of tax reporting through real-time digital systems and e-invoicing, aligning perfectly with their commitment to reducing SME compliance costs by 30% and modernizing the single market.  
EPP endorses the expansion of the One-Stop Shop mechanism as proposed in Article 4, which effectively advances their priority of eliminating bureaucratic fragmentation for cross-border businesses.  
EPP applauds the integration of OECD/G20 minimum tax standards into EU law, matching their longstanding advocacy for fair global competition and closing corporate tax loopholes.  
EPP proposes amending Clause 17(b) to explicitly safeguard member states’ flexibility in setting VAT rates for strategic sectors like tourism, enhancing alignment with national fiscal priorities while maintaining EU coherence.  
EPP strongly agrees the Fiscalis program’s anti-fraud measures, reflecting their manifesto pledge to allocate €269 million for cross-border data-sharing tools that protect EU revenues.

GREEN_EFA entirely sanctions the issue’s prioritization of SME protection, perfectly aligning with their advocacy for economic justice and territorial resilience.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to close the €140 billion VAT gap, emphasizing this directly addresses systemic inequities harming SMEs and public services.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the digital VAT reforms and OSS expansion as critical steps to reduce disproportionate compliance burdens on small businesses.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s focus on combating multinational tax evasion as essential to preserving the European social model from destructive "uberization."  
GREEN_EFA proposes strengthening transparency in cross-border tax data sharing to further empower Eurofisc 2.0’s fraud detection capabilities.

ECR rejects the harmonization of tax residency criteria as a direct infringement on member states' fiscal sovereignty, inconsistent with their principle of national control over taxation.  
ECR opposes the push for a definitive EU VAT system, citing past rejections by the Council and the need to respect national decision-making processes.  
ECR firmly rejects with attempts to circumvent unanimity in tax matters, viewing it as an erosion of member states' veto rights critical to protecting national interests.  
The proposal overlooks the ECR's stance against EU overreach, particularly in creating new regulations that replace member states' authority with centralized tax governance.  
ECR criticizes the issue's approach to corporate tax rules (BEFIT) as undermining competitive federalism and imposing a one-size-fits-all framework contrary to subsidiarity principles.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue’s failure to mandate aggressive action against tax havens within and beyond the EU, which perpetuates profit-shielding by multinationals and the ultra-wealthy.  
GUE_NGL opposes fundamentally the supranational harmonization framework, viewing it as an erosion of national sovereignty that enables corporate tax avoidance rather than curbing it.  
The proposal totally opposes with GUE_NGL’s demand for robust taxation of digital transactions, luxury goods, and concentrated wealth to fund social programs and relieve working families.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects such as binding mechanisms to tax profits where generated, leaving loopholes for large firms while burdening SMEs with compliance costs.  
GUE_NGL condemns the complacency toward preferential regimes for digital nomads and wealthy individuals, which exacerbates inequality contrary to stated green transition goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the significant tax revenue losses exacerbated by the COVID-19 crisis, including a VAT gap estimated at €140 billion in 2018 (potentially rising to €160 billion post-pandemic) and €46 billion lost annually to international tax evasion. It emphasized the urgent need to combat tax fraud, evasion, and harmful tax practices distorting the single market, particularly impacting SMEs, which constitute 99% of EU businesses and face compliance costs 15 times higher than large firms. The resolution welcomed the Commission’s Action Plan for fair taxation, stressing modernization of VAT systems through real-time digital reporting, e-invoicing, and expanding the One-Stop Shop (OSS) to reduce administrative burdens. It called for harmonized tax rules across Member States to address fragmentation, ensure fair competition, and align with OECD/G20 agreements, including the 15% global minimum effective tax rate for multinationals under Pillar Two. The Parliament urged swift adoption of proposals like the Business in Europe: Framework for Income Taxation (BEFIT) to create a unified corporate tax rulebook, alongside reforms to address tax residency ambiguities arising from teleworking and digitalization. It highlighted the Fiscalis program (€269 million budget) and Eurofisc 2.0 as critical tools to enhance cross-border tax cooperation, combat fraud, and improve data quality. Additionally, the resolution stressed balancing tax burdens to avoid shifting from capital to labor, supporting green transition through VAT reforms, and addressing distortions from preferential tax regimes for wealthy individuals and digital nomads.

title: European Central Bank - annual report 2018: REPORT on the European Central Bank Annual Report for 2018 | A9-0016/2020 | European Parliament
background: In 2018-2019, euro area GDP growth slowed to 1.1%, unemployment remained unevenly distributed, and inflation stayed below the ECB's 2% target despite sustained monetary accommodation. The ECB expanded balance sheets to €4.7 trillion, while structural reforms in banking union completion and climate alignment under the Paris Agreement progressed. The Parliament will discuss ECB policy efficacy, financial stability measures, and institutional accountability within its mandate.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the ECB’s integration of climate risks into its strategy review, aligning with EPP’s commitment to sustainable finance and the Paris Agreement.  
EPP endorses enhancing the ECB’s focus on housing affordability metrics within inflation frameworks, proposing harmonized indicators to address rising costs across Member States.  
EPP applauds the ECB’s exploration of a digital currency as a strategic priority, emphasizing its necessity to maintain monetary sovereignty against private sector alternatives.  
EPP urges accelerated progress on banking union completion while recommending strict precondition assessments for the European deposit insurance scheme to ensure financial stability.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for cybersecurity resilience in financial infrastructure, aligning with EPP’s digital agenda for coordinated EU-level threat mitigation.

SD entirely endorses the issue’s emphasis on maintaining expansionary monetary policy to address sluggish inflation and growth, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to prioritizing employment and economic resilience through ECB interventions like the €20 billion APP.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for integrating climate action into ECB operations, particularly applauding demands to phase out high-emission sector bond purchases and collaborate with the EIB on sustainable finance, reflecting SD’s Green New Deal priorities.  
SD fully supports completing the Banking Union through EDIS and Capital Markets Union reforms, recognizing this as critical to strengthening the euro’s global role—a goal central to SD’s vision of deeper economic integration.  
SD endorses the issue’s push for gender-balanced ECB leadership appointments and enhanced transparency, aligning perfectly with SD’s institutional reform agenda to democratize EU economic governance.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of fiscal policy coordination to complement monetary measures, echoing the issue’s caution against over-reliance on ECB tools while national governments delay structural reforms.

ECR rejects the issue's continued reliance on negative interest rates and quantitative easing, fully againsting with their principle that financial stability underpins price stability.  
ECR opposes the €20 billion asset purchase program as dangerously exacerbating equity overvaluations and speculative IPO activities contrary to market discipline principles.  
ECR condemns the issue's failure to address how ECB policies enabled USD 15 trillion in negative-yielding debt, directly contradicting their warnings about distorted credit markets.  
ECR disputes the assumption that prolonged unconventional measures support price stability, highlighting unresolved contradictions with shadow banking expansion risks.  
ECR demands complete discontinuation of corporate bond purchases rather than partial climate adjustments, citing inherent financial instability from sectoral market distortions.

ID rejects the issue's endorsement of negative interest rates and quantitative easing, which have devastated savers and pension systems while failing to stimulate real economic growth as evidenced by stagnant industrial production and youth unemployment.  
ID opposes the ECB's climate action mandate as a politicized overreach that violates its statutory price stability role and infringes on national sovereignty over energy and environmental policies.  
ID condemns the issue's silence on the ECB-induced speculative bubbles and financial instability risks from prolonged monetary expansion exceeding 40% of Eurozone GDP.  
ID entirely disapproves the banking union proposals like EDIS, arguing they enable reckless fiscal policies by indebted member states at the expense of financially responsible nations.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the euro area's economic slowdown, with GDP growth declining to 1.1% in 2019 and inflation remaining below the 2% target at 1.2%, alongside persistent unemployment disparities, particularly youth unemployment exceeding double the EU average. background: The COVID-19 pandemic severely impacted EU economies, straining financial markets and corporate liquidity. resolution: The European Parliament raised amendments to Directive 2014/65/EU (MiFID II) under the Capital Markets Recovery Package to mitigate COVID-19 economic impacts by reducing regulatory burdens while maintaining investor protection. Key measures include exempting corporate bonds with "make-whole clauses" from product governance rules, exempting professional clients and eligible counterparties from mandatory cost disclosures (except for investment advice and portfolio management), and allowing professional clients to opt out of service reports and cost-benefit analyses for switching financial instruments. Retail clients retain the right to receive information on paper. Position limits on commodity derivatives were revised to exclude nascent markets and apply only to critical/significant derivatives (e.g., energy derivatives with 300,000 lots open interest over one year) and agricultural commodities for human consumption. A hedging exemption was introduced for financial entities within predominantly commercial groups, and market makers providing liquidity were exempted from position limits. Securitized derivatives were excluded from position limits. Electronic formats became the default for information delivery, with ESMA mandated to develop regulatory standards for qualitative ancillary activity exemptions and position management controls. The Commission must review the ancillary activity exemption’s impact on EU Emissions Trading System by December 2021 and propose adjustments if needed. Additional provisions include 10% depreciation thresholds for portfolio loss reporting and a 2021 review of MiFID II and Regulation (EU) No 600/2014 to address broader market structure issues.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2021 proposal (COM(2021)0823) under Article 115 TFEU, approving the amended directive aimed at harmonizing tax rules across member states.
